description:
Sterling Silver Earring Workshop, Sterling Silver Earring Workshop
Make your own Sterling Silver summer earrings – Saturday 13th September at Square Edge Art Centre, Palmerston North

Looking for a fun workshop to get your creative juices flowing after a long week in the office? Then come join us on Saturday 13th September at the Square Edge Art Centre in Palmerston North where you will make your own pair of sterling silver earrings in 4 – 5 hours.

When: Saturday 13th September, starts at 10:00 for about 4 – 5 hours (or until you’re done)
Cost: $120 - $150 pp (depending on if you add a gemstone to your design or not. See more info below)
Space: Only 8 spaces available ( book at https://www.rholenesingleton.com/product-page/summer-earrings-workshop )


What to expect:
• Friendly, expert guidance by local metalsmith Rholene Singleton. She will assist you every step of the way ensuring you leave with a beautiful pair of earrings at the end of the day.
• Design your own earrings to create something uniquely yours, or make use of the templates available, which you can embellish as you like.
• You have the option to add a semi-precious cabochon gemstone to your design.
• A selection of refreshments will be available, but you are welcome to bring a light lunch if you feel like the day will get too long without it.
• Relaxed and fun morning enjoyed in the beautiful iconic Square Edge Art Centre in the heart of Palmerston North. View the current artist exhibitions currently on show in the center for free.


Practical Details:
Come and learn the ancient art of silver jewellery making through demonstrations and then giving it a go yourself while you create your own beautiful new summer earrings, using a jewellers saw, blowtorch, gemstone setting tools and more.

• Two options for this workshop:
1. Plain sterling silver earrings - $120 pp
2. Add cabochon gemstones to your design - $150 pp

• 4 – 5 hours of guidance as you create your own piece
• All tools and materials included
• A selection of gemstones to choose from

Your space will be confirmed once payment is received. This workshop is first come, first serve. Space is limited.

To book please go to https://www.rholenesingleton.com/product-page/summer-earrings-workshop

description:
Storytelling On Stage, Do you love storytelling shows like The Moth? Come join the growing art of live storytelling. Learn how to find ideas from your life, craft a compelling narrative, and deliver your story in a confident and entertaining way.

Description
Live storytelling is an artform unto itself, requiring different skills and techniques from standup comedy or prose writing. In this four-part workshop, you’ll learn:

- Creative writing exercises and daily practices to to find meaningful stories from your life
- Tools for crafting a compelling personal narrative
- Techniques to build suspense, drama, and humour into your stories
- Stagecraft and performance skills to heighten and polish your delivery

By the end of the class you'll have
- One or more polished 5-10 minute stories to showcase on stage
- Dozens of ideas to expand upon for future stories
- Writing practices to improve your life as a creative
- Less stage fright and more confidence as a speaker

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Sweat Reflect & Connect with Carolyn Patchell, Sweat – get those endorphins going!
Reflect – review our movements!
Connect – spend time with our classmates!
Sessions:
All Day 10.15am to 4pm $55
Morning 10.15am to 1pm $30
Afternoon 1.15pm to 4pm $30
Our day will start with a 30-minute Dance Fitness session that will include warm-ups but no cool down as we’ll head straight into a Tips and Tuition session. We’ll break down movements, go over cues and choreography, and look at how to increase or decrease intensity (or manage any injuries we might be carrying). We’ll take a break together and some healthy snacks will be provided along with hot drinks. We’ll then head into another Dance Fitness session where you can put your newfound knowledge to use (or just have some fun and party like it’s Friday night)! After a stretch and cooldown, we’ll do a bit of a wrap up over lunch (bring your own) and spend some time relaxing and chatting. Hot drinks will be available, or you can pop out if you need a barista made flat white!
If you’re not staying for the full day, we’ll say farewell after lunch and the rest of us will prepare to greet those coming in for the afternoon session.
The afternoon will start with a Strong Fit session which will contain elements of our Thursday night class. We’ll then move straight into a Tips and Tuition session which will look at all elements of our Strength Based Combo class. This will include form, technique, options, and how to maximise your weekly workouts. We’ll then take a break with some healthy (and easily digested) snacks before we power into a final Strong Fit session. Following the session, we’ll have a decent stretch and take the time to review what we’ve learned, chat amongst ourselves, and say farewell before our day concludes at 4pm.

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1, This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

Description
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

- Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
- Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
- Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
- Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
- Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 2, For those who have completed Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1 recently or have equivalent knowledge. [Please see the Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1 course description for an indication of what is covered]. Course fees: If you are a NZ citizen or hold a NZ Resident/Permanent Resident Visa the course fee is $99 (evidence of eligibility required). If you are here on a Work Visa/Working Holiday Visa the course fee is $189.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Discuss our responsibilities as a bi-cultural nation under ‘Te Tiriti o Waitangi’ and identify underlying Māori values such as: whanaungatanga, pepehā and tikanga
- Discuss the significance of whakapapa as a fundamental Māori world view and confidently describe your family and relationships through this lens
- Form simple sentences to describe parts of your face and body
- Discuss protocol on the marae
- Recognise the importance and use of karakia and be able to recite one correctly
- Recognise the cultural values inherent within different whakataukī (proverbs) and kīwaha (idioms) and be able to correctly recite one of each

Prerequisites
For those who have completed an Introductory 1 course, or equivalent. Note: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and for statistical purposes, some additional information is required as part of the enrolment process.


A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.

description:
Textured Rings - Welcome Spring!, Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
The Art of Mending - Micro Mill, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.

This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.

There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!

In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.

Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.

Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.

Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.

Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.

description:
Torch Fired Enamels - 4 Weeks course, This is a 4 week's block focusing on beautiful glass enamels on copper and silver using the Torch Fired Glass Enamel technique. It is a wonderful way to add colour to your work! The course starts on Sun 4 October and runs for 4 weeks until 25 October, 10am-1pm.

Beginners to jewellery work can use pre-formed shapes to apply their enamels to so they can focus on creating an excellent result. They will be shown how to apply textures and small alterations to the pieces using either hammers or roll printed textures before prepping the metal for the glass enamel.

Those with some metalwork experience can take on a more advanced piece, exploring more complex techniques such as cloisonne.

High quality silver findings are supplied for one to two projects and more are available to purchase if required.

Sterling silver chains are also available if you want to complete the finish of a pendant.

Build your foundational jewellery making skill with this deep dive into enamel technique!

Beginners and advanced students are welcome.

description:
Trap-NZ Workshop, Trap-NZ Workshop
Join us for a hands-on workshop that empowers you to make a difference in your backyard and beyond!



Whether you're a seasoned trapper or just starting out, this free community event will teach you how to use TRAP NZ, New Zealand’s leading predator control platform.



Reino Grundling will show you how to track pests, record trap data, and support conservation efforts that protect our precious native species like kiwi, tūī, and kererū.

📍 Where: Carterton Courthouse, Holloway Street Carterton
📅 When: Saturday 20 September 2025 10am -12 noon
🎟️ Cost: Free
🧰 Bring: Smartphone or tablet (if you have one), enthusiasm, and questions!

What you'll gain:

Tips for setting and managing traps effectively

Skills to use TRAP NZ for recording and reporting activity

Knowledge about the impact of predator control on local biodiversity

Connections with like-minded conservation champions

🌱 Let’s work together to protect what makes Aotearoa unique. Light refreshments provided. This workshop is made possible with funding from WBS.

description:
Victorian Photography Workshop with Brian Scadden, Victorian Photography Workshop with Brian Scadden
DATE: Sunday Sept 28
TIME: 9:30am-1:30pm
LOCATION: Cobblestones Museum, Greytown
AGES: Over 18
COST: $135 per person. Max 5 people.
Come and have a go at wet-plate collodion photography, using authentic materials to produce your own heirloom image as were made 170 years ago. This almost lost art produces one-of-a-kind images on tin or glass plates, which you create and have an image you’ve crafted to take away.

Brian Scadden will be your instructor for this workshop. Brain has been passionate about photography for over 40 years, beginning his career at the National Film Unit in the 1970s before joining Park Road Post Production as Head of Laboratory, Head of Picture, and Restoration Manager. His work in film sparked an interest in early photographic techniques, prompting him to master wet-plate collodion photography. In 2006, he was invited to assist leading wet-plate experts in the USA and has since taught many New Zealanders this challenging process. Jane, who attended Brian’s workshop in 2014, later married him in 2019 and completed a photographic project in Carterton in 2016.
Although Brian retired in 2015, he returned for short-term assignments at Park Road Post and part-time work at Archive NZ, supporting film archiving until mid-2023. Both Brian and Jane continue to shoot with 35mm and 120mm film using vintage cameras from their collection.

NOTE: Link for booking tickets coming soon.

Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.
During the class, Nikki will demonstrate step-by-step techniques on a model while you get to apply your own makeup. You'll have access to professional products and tools to follow along and create your flawless everyday look. It’s fun, interactive, and designed for all skill levels.
"I can’t wait to share my knowledge with you and help you create a makeup routine that leaves you feeling fabulous and confident every day!" – Nikki
What You Need to Know:
No equipment required! We’ll provide all makeup products, brushes, and mirrors.
Bring a willingness to learn and a positive attitude.
Classes are capped at 12-15 participants to ensure personalised guidance.
Arrive 10–15 minutes early to get settled.
Please come with a clean, makeup-free face so you can get the best results.

description:
Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna, Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna
In this hands-on workshop, participants will transform upcycled drink cans into unique wearable pieces — bolo ties or sheriff badges — inspired by Keri-Mei Zagrobelna's work in the exhibition Flaming Star. Using accessible, low-tech techniques, you’ll explore design, embossing, and enamel painting to create a piece you can take home and wear with pride.

Register at

What You’ll Learn:

The cultural background and kaupapa behind bolo ties and sheriff badges.

How to design and plan a wearable artwork.

Techniques for prepping and embossing tin.

How to transfer a design to metal and finish it with enamel paint.

Simple methods to attach your design to a bolo tie or badge backing.

What’s Provided:
All materials, including prepped tin from recycled drink cans, tools, paints, and bolo tie/badge fittings.

An open mind, a steady hand, and any personal imagery or patterns you’d like to incorporate into your design.

description:
Wednesday Morning Jewellery-making In 8 Weeks, This NEW block of morning classes is the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It will run from Wednesday 17 September for 8 weeks until Wednesday 5 November from 10am - 12.30pm.

This class is mixed level, allowing beginners to work alongside advanced students.

Beginners start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.

Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Level 2 students explore chainmaking as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. Their silver project can be a pendant on a handmade chain or a piece of their own design.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques.

Included in the class fee are:
Beginners: a materials pack that includes copper and brass for practising on, 2 gemstones and enough sterling and fine silver to complete the cabochon ring project.
Advanced: students receive a generous credit to spend on materials as they choose. All consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals are also included. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

Our booking system asks for full payment to be made via credit card, PayPal or AfterPay on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this.

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025, Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025
Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a comprehensive Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.

This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.

We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.

This isn’t just about food: it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.

Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit

www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.

For questions, email .

Join my email newsletter to hear about upcoming foraging workshops: https://www.wildbotanica.co.nz/pages/newsletter

description:
Wellington Foraging for Wild Edible Weeds Workshop, Join Felicity of Wild Botanica for a wander around the edges of the Innermost Community gardens to learn about commonly found, wild, edible weeds. Build a relationship with a natural world that is overflowing with abundant, wild, edible, nutritious, medicinal plants. Learn their names & get to know them, along with folklore & stories from the past.

By the end of the workshop you will:
- understand the basic principles of foraging, including sustainable harvesting
- feel confident in identifying 10-15 wild edible plants
- know about their nutritional & medicinal benefits
- know about common toxic/dangerous plants to avoid when foraging
- know about the best ways to prepare your foraged greens for maximum nutritional benefit & flavor
- feel empowered to include foraged greens in your everyday diet

Walk away with hands on, practical skills & knowledge that you can use in your own life.

Investment includes hands on wild weed walk & discussion, cup of foraged herbal tea & wildly delicious foraged snack.

description:
Wet-plate Photography Tintype Introduction Workshop, *Note, completion needs to be at 1pm
Create a wet-plate photograph with Brian and Jane from Brass and Glass Photographic Alchemy. You will see the magic of silver and light combining to create an authentic, 19th century tintype.

Beginning with a short presentation into the process, you will then have the opportunity to hand-craft your own portrait tintype to take home with you. With care, your priceless heirloom photograph will last for decades without fading or changing colour.

This almost-lost-art produces a one-of-a-kind image, using authentic materials and a bellows camera. Be prepared to experience the need to sit still for up to several seconds, it's not as easy as you may think!

Bookings essential, with a maximum of 5 people for this workshop.

description:
What I Wish I Knew About Index Funds 5 Years Ago, People often ask me, “How do I best start investing?” It’s a great question—but not something I can explain in just a few minutes. That’s why I created this workshop.

This is a beginner-friendly, educational session focused on index fund investing—what it is, how it works, and how to actually get started. I’ll walk you through the full process: from understanding the basics to setting up your accounts, learning the key jargon, and knowing how to choose a fund that fits you.

We’ll cover important things like fees, tax, coverage, hedging, and more—things most people overlook when they first start. It’s not just theory. You’ll leave with a clear understanding of what to look for and how to take action confidently.

I’m not a financial adviser—this isn’t personal advice. It’s everything I wish someone had explained to me earlier. Because when you understand the process and use a simple strategy like dollar-cost averaging, you really can set yourself up for the long term.

If you’ve never invested before or just want to finally make sense of it all, this workshop is for you.

Foraging and Growing Workshops coming to Wellington all the way from Chch. No need for prior knowledge we will learn everything from scratch.
I'm hitchhiking all the way from Chch to Whangarei and back to Chch with a purpose to pass on some knowledge while visiting my dear friends.

During this workshop we will learn to substitute our salads, teas, seeds for the rest of our lives, save a lot of money while contributing to nature thriving again, with incredible insights all through life while reconnecting with nature everytime a bit more. A contribution to mental and physical wellbeing while having an excuse to go outside, treasure hunting with your family, neighbours, friends or solo💚
No prior knowledge is necessary. Just your enthusiasm to learn, ready ears and ready to try new things and sense of humour😊
We will have a very necessary 30-40min introduction talk with some unique understandings of what plants are, how we can help them and how they can help us. All with good scientific attitude. We will also learn some tools/attitudes to foraging and then walk around and learn about 10-12 plants that can be found nearly in every backyard during this workshop, which out of my experience have proven to be most practical and easiest to remember.
3 hours is a must to do all the above.

description:
Workshop Series: Exploring 'Search and Reflect’ with Jake Baxendale, Search and Reflect, by the legendary drummer & improviser John Stevens, is a compilation of pieces/exercises/activities/vehicles for developing the collaboration, listening, trust and communal and convivial spirit required for group musical improvisation.
Informed by his own research and performance practice in improvisation, Jake Baxendale will lead an exploration of the book, choosing a number of pieces to perform with the participants, showing how its exacting, precise investigation of musical elements provides a blueprint for friendly, open & free musical happenings.
About John Stevens: One of the founding fathers of free improvisation in Britain. In the mid-'60s, Stevens helped found Spontaneous Music Ensemble (SME), an influential group that included most of England's top experimental jazz musicians.
About Jake Baxendale: a saxophonist and composer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Jake Baxendale performs regularly at venues throughout the city, and has performed extensively overseas.
https://jakebaxendale.com/

description:
Alzheimers Marlborough Art, Crafts and Collections Trail 2025, Alzheimers Marlborough Art, Crafts and Collections Trail 2025
Coinciding with World Alzheimers Month our 4th Annual Art, Crafts & Collections Trail is once again bringing art to your community and showcasing some of our local, wonderfully talented artists, while helping us provide services for people living with dementia and their families and carers.

We have a large selection of artists, craftspeople and specialty collectors displaying their art in their own studios, or in shared spaces in the Marlborough Alzheimers Centre and a selection of galleries around Blenheim.

Whether you're an admirer of visual arts, handcrafted masterpieces, or unique collectibles, this weekend promises an inspiring array of works to explore. Visitors can engage directly with artists, gaining insights into their creative processes and the stories behind their works. Families and friends are encouraged to come together to celebrate creativity while supporting a meaningful cause. This very special fundraising event helps us meet the increasing demand for the range of services we offer to support local people affected by dementia, and their families.

The Art Trail is a self-drive event with tickets available for just $30 per person, on sale from 19th August at the following places:

- Marlborough Alzheimers Centre, 8 Wither Road, Blenheim - Monday to Friday, 9am-3pm
- Scenic Hotel Marlborough, 65 Alfred Street, Blenheim - Open 7 days 9am - 9pm
- Agrivit Ltd, 29 High Street, Renwick - Monday to Friday, 8am-4.30pm
- Marlborough Art Gallery, Library Building, 15 High Street, Blenheim - Tuesday to Friday, 10am – 4pm, Weekends, 1pm – 4pm

Tickets are valid for both days of the Art Trail. The tickets show where to find each exhibitor, a brief outline of their style and an illustration showing the amazing talent on display.

Devonshire Teas will also be available at the Marlborough Alzheimers Centre, 8 Wither Road for $5 per person during the event.

We are encouraging our very supportive Marlborough community to gather their friends together and enjoy a special weekend out and about. It’s a great opportunity to see some amazing art and talk to some of our wonderfully talented artists living and working here Marlborough. You may even be able to purchase a favourite piece of art as a gift or for your own enjoyment.

All funds raised from our Art Trail remain in Marlborough.

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn
Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.

--

Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.

Learn more here > https://citygallery.org.nz/events/art-and-ai-brit-bunkley-in-conversation-with-megan-dunn/

IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Archive, single channel video, 2025

description:
Asia After Five: Experiences in Taiwan, About the event
The Asia New Zealand Foundation and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office Wellington are hosting an evening of stories and insights from New Zealanders who have studied, worked and lived in Taiwan. Hear from the Foundation's Leadership Network members and Taiwan alumni as they share their experiences and reflect on future opportunities for Kiwis in Taiwan.
Our Asia After Five events are interactive. You will have a chance to ask questions, network with others and learn more about Asia.
Event details
Date:  Thursday 25 September 2025
Time:  5:30pm-7:00pm
Venue:  Asia New Zealand Foundation, Level 16, Fujitsu Tower, 141 The Terrace (access to building via Cable Car Lane before 6pm)
This event is free to attend, but please RSVP for catering purposes.
This event is a collaboration between the Asia New Zealand Foundation Te Whītau Tūhono and Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New Zealand (TECO).
Our speakers
Ema Kato
Ema Kato is a recent graduate from Victoria University of Wellington with a degree in Communication, specialising in intercultural communication and Mandarin. Having lived in Japan, Taiwan and New Zealand, Ema is passionate about cross-cultural exchange and will return to Taiwan next year to pursue advanced language study and a master’s program at National Taiwan University with the Huayu and Taiwan Scholarships.
Tom Durkin
Tom is currently based in Auckland, working in Private Wealth at Craigs Investment Partners. Having studied Mandarin as a part of his degree at the University of Otago, he has long held an interest in Chinese language and culture. Tom spent two months travelling in Taiwan at the end of 2023. During this time, he joined parts of the Taipei Hui with the Asia New Zealand Foundation Leadership Network, worked with a farmer in Chiayi and spent two weeks at Fo Guang Shan Buddhist monastery in Southern Taiwan. His participation in the recent Shanghai Hui with the Asia New Zealand Leadership Network sparked a desire to re-engage and immerse in Chinese culture. Tom has recently been accepted to study at the National Taiwan Normal University - Mandarin Training Center from later this year. He's looking forward to sharing his experiences and hearing more on others' perspectives of the New Zealand-Taiwan relationship.
Lauren Pattermore
Lauren Pattemore is an early-career journalist based in New Zealand, with contributions to Stuff, the Otago Daily Times, Crux and Radio New Zealand. She recently completed a media internship with the Asia New Zealand Foundation in Taipei, working with TaiwanPlus. In 2024, she was named runner-up for Best Up and Coming Journalist at the Voyager Media Awards. She holds a Bachelor of Communication from Massey University, where she specialised in expressive arts and journalism.
Rob Eland
Rob was the sole New Zealand recipient of the Taipei City Chinese Learning Scholarship in 2018, selected by Mayor Justin Lester. With the scholarship, he took a sabbatical from work and travelled to Taipei, where he lived from mid-2018 to early 2019. During this time, Rob studied full-immersion Chinese at NTNU's Mandarin Training Center (MTC) and took part in several New Zealand–Taiwan cross-cultural activities, including supporting then-Deputy Mayor Jill Day and a group of New Zealand performing arts students during their visit to Taiwan. Rob returned to New Zealand in 2019, but he looks forward to heading back to Taiwan again soon.

description:
Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson), Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson)
🔥 Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks 🔥


🌟 Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party 🌟


Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.

And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!

Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.

1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social

Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.

Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.

Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.

Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼

This event is unique in its focus on Wairarapa’s flourishing wedding industry. It is a great opportunity for couples planning their own weddings to look for inspiration from other local couples, for friends and families of brides to reminisce on the weddings. It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA
On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.

***

PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK 🩷 LA VITA IN ROSA 🩷 LEVEN IN ROZE 🩷 LA VIDA EN ROSA 🩷 LA VIE EN ROSE 🩷 ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO 🩷 AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.

***

CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.

What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.

Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!

Dress Code: PINK!

Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!

Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!

EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:

02-0343-0003801-007

ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.

Please give generously.

LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.

NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.

RAIN DATE: TBC

***

This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.

#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban

Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening

This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer

And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump

Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness

Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.

To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.

CUBAN☆FUSION © 2005 - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists | www.cubanfusion.co.nz | | 021-621-245

Join us for a fun-filled day featuring :

In the lead-up to the event, we’re also collecting donations like pet food, blankets, and other supplies—feel free to drop them off at Greta Point Cafe, and we’ll deliver them to the SPCA on the day.

description:
Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero, Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.
Tour and kōrero
Mark your calendars for 19 September, the anniversary of the 1893 Electoral Act that granted New Zealand women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
To celebrate Suffrage Day, join a 45-minute kōrero and tour of the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
Tours are open to visitors of all ages (age 6+). Booking is not required.
Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the start of the tour.
The ongoing struggle for equal rights
Come along to the National Library to learn about the journey New Zealand women took to gain the right to vote and about the ongoing struggle for equal rights.
View the 1893 petition that led to the creation of the Electoral Act 1893, which was signed into law on 19 September 1893.
Hear stories about wāhine toa like Meri Te Tai Mangakāhia (Te Rarawa) and suffragists Kate Sheppard, Ada Wells and maybe an ancestor of your own.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Celebrating Mahuru Māori: He wheako reorua o He Tohu and Pipitea walking tour — Mahuru Māori 2025, This Mahuru Māori, join a reorua (bilingual) He Tohu experience and hīkoi around Pipitea to celebrate te reo Māori and the unique hītori (history) of Pipitea. Deepen your understanding about ingoa tūturu (original place names) and the wāhi where He Tohu currently sits.
A reorua | bilingual tour of He Tohu and Pipitea
Join us and embark on a haerenga (journey) together to connect to the ancestors and our shared past. The tour will begin at He Tohu — a permanent exhibition of three iconic constitutional taonga that shape Aotearoa New Zealand.
* 1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
* 1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
* 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
These taonga are significant because they shaped who we are as a nation and will shape what we become in the future.
"Ka mua, ka muri | Walking backwards into the future"
A hīkoi around Pipitea
After the He Tohu tour, join us on a half-hour bilingual hīkoi (walk) around key sites in Pipitea of cultural significance.
There are slight inclines in places, but we will be walking on the pavement for the tour. If the huarere (weather) is looking inclement, please bring warm clothing, a raincoat, or an umbrella. If the weather is too bad, we will postpone the event, so please register so that we can notify you about the cancellation.
Shared kai
During the kaupapa, knowledge, pātai (questions), and reflections will flow between us. At the end we’ll have kai timotimo (snacks). You are welcome to bring snacks to share.
This event is suitable for all ages. Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the tour starts.
Nau mai, haere mai!
Book your spot
Places are limited so email us to book your spot.
Please include your contact details and the number of people in your party.
Email — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz
Celebrate te reo Māori
Reorua (bilingual) speaking kaimahi will host your taenga mai ki te whare, visit. Some will be kaimahi tangata whenua and some will be kaimahi Pākehā, Tauiwi rānei. Like us all, this mahi (work) is for us and our descendants — mō tātou, me ō tātou uri, haere ake nei.
Toi te kupu, toi te mana, toi te reo Māori! | Hold fast to the word, to the mana and to the Māori language!
Image: Kaiārahi leading the hīkoi through Pipitea. Photo by Mark Beatty

description:
Community Evening Trimester 2 2025, About Ignite:
Ignite Consultants is a student-run charitable organisation that provides free and creative advice to charities and social organisations across Aotearoa. All of our consultants are passionate and talented student-volunteers who are driven by their desire to foster social change. Our vision is to help organisations to maximise their impact through harnessing the fresh perspectives of university students. 
We run two project cycles per year which coincide with the university semesters, each lasting for a duration of 9 weeks. Each team consists of a local charity, 5-6 students, a project manager (a person who has been through the Ignite Consultants experience before) and a professional mentor who has experience in consulting and/or the industry the organisation works in. 
About the Event:
Ignite's Community Evening is a special occasion where our consultants share what they have learnt, created and experienced over the past nine weeks. This event is an opportunity to learn about the remarkable charities we have collaborated with this semester, to enjoy delicious food and to extend our heartfelt thanks to all our supporters. 
This semester, attendees will get to hear presentations from the teams who have worked with WELLfed, Take10, Orange Sky, PACE and The Charitable Recycling Trust. 
To join us virtually, please click on the link below:

description:
DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp 2025, Kia ora DEBRA New Zealand whanau !
Save the dates - DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp, Wellington, Friday 22 - Sunday 24 August 2025.
We are very happy to announce that we are planning a get-together for the NZ EB whanau and a few Aussie families in Wellington in August. We really hope you can join us - it will be wonderful to see you!
This event is a great opportunity to meet other families, connect with old friends and make wonderful new ones, learn from each other and from valuable talks about EB issues, and have time to relax and enjoy a couple of days in Wellington city - the creative capital! We're keen to hear about any particular topics you would like to hear about.
Everyone is welcome including extended family and friends, caregivers, and healthcare professionals.
Dates: Friday 22nd August (check-in from 3pm with informal meet and greet from 5.00pm), to Sunday 24th August (finishing 2pm after a farewell lunch)
Event location: Wellington City, venue to be confirmed
Registration will be launched in early May - please stay tuned for further details!
Your registration fee will cover the conference, meals and children’s activities from Friday evening to Sunday lunch time, but it does not cover accommodation (amount to be confirmed), travel or airport transfers.
DEBRA NZ will provide some limited assistance with accommodation and travel costs if needed, subsiding flights for the person attending with EB.
Please contact debra@debra.org.nz if you would like to apply for this support.
There will be more information soon.
We need an idea of numbers so please get in touch as soon as possible!
Email: debra@debra.org.nz with any questions and let us know if you are interested in attending.
Nga mihi nui,
Anna, Lea and the DEBRA NZ team
debra@debra.org.nz

ENM/Poly Speed Dating, Are you looking to meet like-minded people who embrace polyamory? Join us for an exciting evening of Poly Speed Dating! This event is for those who practice or are interested in consensual non-monogamy, offering a safe and inclusive environment to connect and potentially spark new friendships/relationships.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

We will have a private function space for this event.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

description:
Fareham Journey Free Cohousing Information & Tour, Fareham Journey is building a sustainable cohousing community in Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston and they are looking for people who share their kaupapa to create this with us. The Fareham property has extensive grounds which includes a historic home, and established organic gardens, an orchard, and fields. It even has an arts community on site.

We run these free cohousing information and tour events on the third Sunday of every month, from noon until 2pm at Fareham, 80 Underhill Road, Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston in the South Wairarapa.

Learn about the Fareham Journey and our vision to create a sustainable and supportive community and how you can get involved. We invite you to bring a plate of vegetarian food to join us for a shared meal in the historic homestead, Fareham House, followed by the tour.

Ensure you RSVP to attend at https://farehamjourney.nz/rsvp/
label: Community & Culture

description:
Father's Day Quiz, Put your general knowledge to the test while supporting a great cause at the Father's Day Quiz!
Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. Your generous donations are greatly appreciated and make a significant difference. Once Cooper is fully trained, he will be placed with a visually impaired person for the rest of his working life. We believe that as the Scots Community bands together, your support can change a life.
To learn more or to make a donation, visit our Givealittle page.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Fermented Quiz Night (Brewtown), Every Thursday fortnight is quiz night at one of Upper Hutt's best venues - Fermented at Brewtown!
Hosted by Sam from Gee Quiz and kicking off at 6.30pm, the quiz offers five rounds of trivia that's not too hard, not too easy, but includes content that relates to you and your crew!
So if you've got some street smarts, a good attitude, and a dash of luck, you'll be a good chance on the night. Add to the mix some bonus games, great food & drink, a stack of prizes, great banter and laughs aplenty, it's the place to be on a Thursday for a rollicking good time!
We advise booking in your team here, specifying you are coming to quiz night: https://fermented.co.nz/reservations
label: Community & Culture

description:
Free Bike Fix-Ups with Bikespace, Is your bike not working? Whether it's clunky gears, flat tyres or brakes needing a rejig, we want to help!
We've teamed up with the crew at Bikespace to put on this FREE drop-in to get your bike running at the top of its game! An experienced bike mechanic will be at the Newtown Community Centre to help you fix up your bike and teach you a few skills to keep your bike running smoothly.
The team will also be able to help you registering your bike on 529 Garage - a project aimed to prevent bike theft.
Please note: If you know that something needs replacing on your bike - e.g. brake pads or an inner tube, please bring it with you as the Bikespace crew will not have replacement parts here.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends Quiz @ 1852, Wellington, Friends Quiz @ 1852, Wellington
Your job may be a joke, you're probably broke, your love is likely D.O.A., but we've got something to cheer you up.... for Gee Quiz is at it again, this time bringing Friends trivia to Wellington's favourite establishment, 1852, on Saturday 4th October!

In what will be a frivolity-filled Friends fest, you and your team will face off against other Friends fanatics over five furious big screen rounds to battle for top spot and a flurry of fabulous prizes!! In true Gee Quiz fashion, we'll also have fantastically-fun bonus games and the dreaded Alphabetical round, where your team will frantically answer 26 fast-fire questions as the time tick downs.

A team ticket (up to 6 players) is $90 ($15 per head for team of six), so get out of second gear and book your ticket today!!

Booking here: https://www.trybooking.com/nz/YML

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Tales from the Vaults Tour, Tales from the Vaults.
Find out who is in and who is out of some of Karori cemetery’s most substantial dwellings. Note: tours do not enter vaults or try them out for size. 
The tour duration is 1 hour 45mins.
This tour is suitable for people with moderate fitness. The route mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness. Surefootedness is required. This tour involves approximately 2km of walking, with some slow paced but uphill stints

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes long
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: National Monuments (Dec 2025), The two main stops on the tour are the Cemeteries’ two national Monuments – the Tangiwai disaster and Prime Minister Peter Fraser.  We will review what happened at Tangiwai and especially the bravery of the trains crew and in addition, what the court of inquiry found about the safety of the bridge. 
Peter Fraser is generally regarded as one of NZ’s best Prime Ministers of the 20th century, and we explore his initiatives in public health and education and also his leadership during WW2.
These are just two of the several stops we will make.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you 1 hour before the tour start time by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets
label: Community & Culture

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever, Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 5 OCT

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 5 October 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

You may also like the following events from Walk Tours NZ:
Next Saturday, 6th September, 03:00 am, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour in Wellington
Next Sunday, 7th September, 03:00 am, Free LGBTI rainbow walk tour (Turquoise tour) in Wellington
This October, 19th October, 03:00 am, A Change Is Coming walk tour in Wellington

description:
He Kura Toi Tangata: Gold Card Tour, Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum invites our golden folk to experience an intimate, guided tour of photography exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The tour will continue throughout the museum, weaving through Wellington stories and taonga currently on display.
After the tour, we’ll sit down for a chat and a warm cuppa in the old Harbour Board room, with a little sweet something to finish off the afternoon.
This tour is part of the Takurua Hauora: Winter Wellness event series developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
Tickets are limited. Booking is essential.
Note: International visitor admissions are not included.

Sunday 24 August | 10:30am–12pm
$5 for SuperGold Card holders

Book online or over the phone on: 04 472 8904
Image: Ngāi Te Rangi kuia in attending the hearing of the urgent claim concerning the use of te reo Māori in the public service. 2024. Wellington. Image credit: Tessa Chrisp.

description:
Hōkai Tahi Winter Woodlands Pizza Evening, We’re inviting you to a cozy night out with heart.
Our Winter Woodlands Pizza Evening is a special fundraiser supporting Hōkai Tahi.
Based in the Wairarapa, Hōkai Tahi walks alongside women and whānau through pregnancy, baby loss, and the early years of parenting - offering time, space, and resources when they are needed most.
Indulge in a delicious 3-course meal (wood-fired pizza included, of course!) with non-alcoholic drinks provided.
A limited bar menu will be available, or feel free to BYO.
Alongside your meal, enjoy live music, a live auction of locally donated treasures, and for those feeling adventurous, a short glow worm walk through the native bush (don’t forget your torch, sturdy shoes, and warm layers - hot water bottles welcome!).
Details:
Watermill Bakery, 33 Blakes Road, Mt Holdsworth
Saturday 1st November 2025
5:30–8:30pm
$75 per adult - $20 per child (under 14)
Look out for our friendly parking warden in hi-vis on arrival and simply give your name to be guided in.
Please note there’s no reception at the venue, so make any arrangements before you head our way.
Share an evening of great food, live entertainment, and woodland magic - all in support of a truly worthwhile cause.
Every ticket sold helps Hōkai Tahi continue supporting local whānau through life’s most tender moments.
label: Community & Culture

Follow our Instagram @houseofmarama to keep up to date with our events.
--------
Ballroom is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Ballroom check out this link: 
https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. 
The HOUSE OF MARAMA honours the whenua in which this event is able to take place on, belonging to the true sovereigns: 
Te Ātiawa iwi. We also stand in solidarity with indigenous peoples across the world facing injustice. 
TOITŪ TE TIRITI
FREE PALESTINE
FREE CONGO
FREE WEST PAPUA
FREE KANAKY
FREE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE EVERYWHERE. 
LAND BACK.
Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on any of our socials for any questions or concerns you may have.
---------
BALLROOM TERMINOLOGY*
OTA = Open to All, not limited to a specific gender identity/expression, or category style.
SHAKE VS SHAKE = We wanna see you shake that ass, shake that hair, shake those thighs. We want to see why YOU have the best shake.
FACE = Serve FACE, highlighting your structure, eyes, teeth, skin and nose. Makeup allowed.
BODY =The ability to sell your confidence in yourself, specifically through your body (not through sex appeal).
PERFORMANCE = Performing and battling in a style of Vogue (Old Way, New Way, or Vogue Fem).

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY, Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE PUKERUA BAY SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
3-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
3.15-3.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
3.45-4pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

Also check out other Meetups in Porirua, Nonprofit events in Porirua.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kareoke & Disco Fundraiser, Ultimate Kareoke Disco Fundraiser Night! Let’s send me to Australia in style!
Malo families & friends, as you all know I got picked for the Wellington Samoa cricket tour to Australia — but I need your help to cover my ticket, kit, and subs. This is my FINAL DANCE to fund this dream, and I’m counting on you to bring the vibes, the laughs, and the support!
Date, place & vibes:
Saturday 6th Sep
Cutlers Entertainment, The Hutt
6:00 PM – Midnight
Let’s light up the floor and keep the good energy rolling all night long!
What’s happening:
Kareoke & Disco Party Night — you bring the voice, we bring the glory!
Cash prizes: Winner takes home $500
, 2nd, 3rd and 4th places take home a NSW or Maroon hoodie (your pick)

Sing solo or in a crew — 10 lucky peeps get to perform the beat between 9:30pm to 11pm
Entry to perform: only $50 per seat (book fast — only 10 spots!)
Tickets to watch and dance: Online $20 | Door $25
How to join the fun:
Want to sing? Message me NOW to grab your seat!

Kareoke entry deadline: 30th Aug — don’t miss out!
Song submission for the night: 1st Sep — we’ll be ready to roll!
Tickets to dance & watch: inbox me — I’ll send your number once you book and pay

Payment - Te Mana
03-0531-0113530-001 (Please ref your FB name)
Support the dream:
Can’t perform? Come cheer, dance, and enjoy with great food & drink deals!

VIPs & judges will be on hand to spice up the night and crown our karaoke king/queen

Share this post, invite your crew, and flood the dance floor with love — the more, the merrier!
DJ & vibes:
DJ Mana spinning a vibrant mix of Pacific tunes for all ages
Epic lighting, dance circles, and island-flare vibes that’ll have you smiling all night
Why I’m asking for your help:
October tour in Australia is my first cricket adventure abroad — I want to represent our Tokelau family with pride.
Every dollar brings me closer to my dream and to stepping onto that pitch with heart!
Let’s make this night legendary. Your support means the world to me — bring family, friends, neighbours, and your best dance moves!
Special prizes for our male/ female best dressed outfit on the night

Let's Sketch at Kai Tahi in Porirua, Kai Tahi (eat together), is a food, retail, and community space in a former factory. The ground floor market hall has an industrial feel and hosts a range of eateries and retail outlets. There is plenty of seating. The adjoining foyer and mezzanine level are flooded with natual light and offer different view and perspectives. If the weather is good, step out the door to the foreshore. Pātaka Art Museum and Abondoned Brewery are a short walk away.

Kai Tahi is located at 20 Parumoana St, Porirua City Centre. About 15 minutes walk from the train Station.

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today

Also check out other Kids events & activities in Waikanae.
