description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.

description:
PANEL TALK: BALLROOM CULTURE, Ballroom is a queer subculture. The Ballroom scene today was created by Black and Latinx trans women in the late 1960s in Harlem, New York. Since then, ballroom has taken over the world with scenes in Europe, Asia, Africa, South America and Oceania.
The Aotearoa Ballroom scene was ignited by Māori and MVPFAFF+ youth in Tāmaki Makaurau over 10 years ago, and has since inspired other leaders across the motu to forge their own Ballroom communities in their respective cities. 
In preparation for The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, hear from influential figures who have made significant contributions to their own scenes. With international Icons and Legends coming to Aotearoa for the first time, there has never been a better time to learn and enhance our own knowledge and experience of Ballroom. 
Featuring ballroom leaders Arturo Mulan (NYC, USA), Matyouz Royalty (Paris, EU), Jaycee Iman (Auckland, NZ), Karamera Marama and Romé Marama.
Panellists
Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the International House of Miyake-Mugler) (he/him) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the beating heart of Ballroom, NYC. Arturo has been involved in Ballroom since 1996 and has established himself as a visionary choreographer and community leader, with the title of NYC father of the international mainstream House of Miyake Mugler. His influence spans competitive wins, global workshops, and has dedicated his time to bringing diverse artistry into ballroom culture, and ballroom culture into diverse arts opportunities; such as Legendary - Season 2 (HBO Max), Brooklyn Nets performances, Cats the Jellicle Ball on Broadway and more.
Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the International House of Gorgeous Gucci) (he/she/they) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the Paris Ballroom scene and is the creator of the ‘Fashion Killa’ category. They discovered voguing and ballroom culture in 2009 during a trip to New York which they believe changed their life. Their impact within ballroom spans several categories: Commentator vs Commentator, Hands Performance, Runway and Fashion categories. Matyouz has become a staple commentator and music artist within the ballroom community, with a repertoire of modelling and influencer opportunities in their resumé.
Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman aka Jaycee Tanuvasa (she/her) is an inter-disciplinary Sāmoan artist and choreographer of fa’afafine, femme queen & trans experience. Born and raised in South Auckland, Tāmaki Makaurau, her work is firmly rooted in community as she places autonomy and story sovereignty at the core of each of her projects. She celebrates the fullness of young, queer, brown life and works collaboratively to create empowering and responsive reflections of this across a range of media such as theatre, film and activations.
Founding Mother Karamera Marama (he/they) is an emerging multi-disciplinary, queer and Māori artist professing in Graphic Design, Dance and Performance Arts. They are the Co-Founding Mother of the trailblazing Kiki House of Marama, Co-Director of Pōneke-based queer arts collective OVĀ and member of the Aotearoa Ballroom council. Karamera has been involved in Ballroom since 2020 competing in Performance and Fashion categories and winning numerous grand prizes across Aotearoa & so-called Australia respectfully; most notably within Vogue Fem categories.
Founding Mother Romé Marama (he/him) whakapapa to Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Kahungunu, Ngāti Hineuru, and Ngāti Tūwharetoa. He is an emerging multi-disciplinary performing artist, as well as the Co-Founding Mother of the House of Marama and Co-Founding Director of OVĀ. For the past five years, he has been a prominent figure in Aotearoa Ballroom, both competing and facilitating events. Renowned in the RUNWAY category, Romé has secured multiple Grand Prize titles across Aotearoa and so-called Australia.
Facilitator: Kasi Marama (he/him/barb) 
Kasi Valu ('Eua, Ma'ufanga, Lapaha / Tonga) Full-Time sergeant of Gag city #Barbz Part-Time hater of the Rihanna #Navy and Casual staff member of the #Beyhive. Retired Hater of the #swifties and founding member of Azealia Banks support group. Actor, Writer, and Producer. His work currently centres on the experiences, wit, complexities, and universality of Pacific peoples, all whilst being an all-time fia botz, professional guesser and self-deprecating in this miserable world.

description:
Pacific Peoples and the Underclass of Aotearoa New Zealand: Repositioning the Narrative, In 2018, over 380,000 people in Aotearoa New Zealand identified with at least one Pacific ethnicity. Despite being a youthful and growing community, Pacific peoples are statistically entrenched in a cycle of disadvantage that cannot be ignored.
In almost every measure—health, education, income, home ownership, and justice—Pacific people are overrepresented in poor outcomes.
We are not just facing a Pacific problem; we are looking at the face of New Zealand’s underclass—systemic, intergenerational, and largely invisible in mainstream policy conversations. Despite progress for some groups, the Pacific population remains on the wrong side of the statistical ledger.
Pacific peoples experience:
• The highest rates of avoidable hospitalisations and chronic conditions.
• Worst material deprivation across nearly every indicator.
• Persistently low home ownership rates.
• A widening education achievement gap, often masked by ethnic averages.
• Underrepresentation in decision-making, leadership, and governance roles.
While initiatives for Māori advancement are critical and must continue, Pacific peoples require their own distinct policy lens. A “one-size-fits-all” approach under a pan-ethnic umbrella risks making the Pacific experience invisible.

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
September Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

description:
Site Visit - Studio of Pacific Architecture - Te Aro Double-Header!, Join us on Wednesday 20 August, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of two very different but geographically close projects in Te Aro. The National War Memorial and FPC Martin Square are both undergoing major refurbishment - join us for a look behind the scenes!
National War Memorial: Refurbishing a Wellington Icon
Step behind the scaffolding and witness the National War Memorial Project – a complex seismic strengthening project where heritage sensitivity is of utmost importance. With construction works being carried out by Maycroft Construction, join us for the rare opportunity to explore a significant piece of the capital’s cultural fabric.
Known to many as the backdrop of ANZAC Day commemorations, this national memorial is undergoing a meticulous refurbishment to ensure its legacy endures for generations to come.
 What’s Happening On Site:
Seismic strengthening of the tower and bell frame 
Stone remediation to preserve its historic façade
Asphalt roofing works
The real challenge? Balancing modern engineering with heritage preservation. Every upgrade is being carried out with deep respect for the building’s historical significance.

Then, just around the corner, we will move on to another refurbishment project – at a much different scale and for a very different purpose!
 FPC Martin Square: from Workshop to Office Space
Leading industrial design-and-build specialists First Principles Constructors are celebrating seven years of innovation with a bold move - into a brand-new headquarters in central Wellington. Take a look inside the transformation of a former engineering workshop into the new HQ for FPC. With exposed services, raw materials, and an industrial aesthetic, this compact yet clever refurbishment shows how much can be achieved in a small urban footprint. Construction is well underway by Aoraki Construction, with completion coming up in September.
What’s Happening On Site:
•     Structural steel installation, new roofing, cladding, a new concrete mezzanine slab
•     Interior fit-out works
•     Full building services upgrades
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Wednesday, 20th August, meet at 2.45pm for a 3.00pm start at the National War Memorial
📍 LOCATION: Meet at the National War Memorial (19 Buckle Street) to explore this site first. We will then walk over to 21 Martin Square as a group, for the next site visit.
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 18 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots. (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 🎉 After the site visits, unwind with drinks and nibbles sponsored by First Principles Constructors at a nearby venue (TBC) – a chance to connect, reflect, and chat all things design and construction.
🧡 Huge thanks to Studio of Pacific Architecture, Aoraki Construction, Maycroft Construction, and First Principles Constructors for teaming up to make this event possible.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Sophie Thorn – Victoria University Photography Collection, A tour of the photographs from Ngā Puhipuhi o Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington Art Collection
Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington holds a nationally significant collection of works of art which is under the care of Te Pātaka Toi Adam Art Gallery. Known as Ngā Puhipuhi o Te Herenga Waka, or 'the feathers which adorn the waka', over half of this collection can be found on display in the various buildings on the university campuses at any one time.
For this special outing, join the gallery’s Kaiwhakarākei, Curator Collections, Sophie Thorn, for an afterhours tour of the Hunter Building focusing on the photography in the collection.
We will see photographic works by Lucien Rizos, Ans Westra, Peter Preyer, Joyce Campbell, Fiona Pardington, Ann Noble and Chris Corson Scott.
We are meeting at the foyer of the Hunter Building. This is the big set of glass doors off gate 2 between the two sets of lights on Kelburn Parade.
As the tour begins at 6pm we would suggest,that people park in the Hunter Building carpark (coming in Gate 1 (right at the bend between Salamanca Road and Kelburn Parade). While these are reserved spaces for staff after 5:30pm parking is a bit of a free-for-all on campus after hours.
Thursday, 11 September, 6:00pm start, Meet at Hunter Building (Main Entrance off Kelburn Parade)

description:
Speed Dating 30-43, 40-55, Speed Daters will be split into 2 age groups which will run simultaneously. There will be opportunity to mix with the other group during the break. We will have a private area of the venue for this event. Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Speed dating does not have to be stressful or frightening; you will be pleasantly surprised how fun and positive it is.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band
Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!

If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.

This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.

Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025

Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)

—

Doors open 7:30pm

Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.

Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.

Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.

Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.

Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.

description:
Suffrage Day Walking Tour Bolton Street Cemetery, It's Suffrage Day on Friday 19 September, marking the day in 1893 when New Zealand became the first self-governing country in the world to grant women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.

To celebrate our pioneer women, and those who signed the Suffrage Petition in 1893, we're taking a walk through the cemetery, talking about the roles of settler women from 1840 onwards.

We'll meet at the Seddon Memorial at the top of the cemetery (by Anderson Park) in time to set off at 11.00am, and we'll finish at the Museum in Bolton Street about 12.30pm.

This tour is suitable for all ages, but full mobility is required. Cost $10 per person, children under 12 free, and good dogs on leads welcome.

description:
THREE JOYFUL HOUSES - AOTEAROA FESTIVAL OF ARCHITECTURE - SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER, THREE JOYFUL HOUSES by IAN ATHFIELD
SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER @ FUTUNA CHAPEL - KARORI
Three joyful houses, three families and three client stories about the commissioning, designing, building and living in homes designed by Ian Athfield.
SPENCER and DIANE LOGAN
1974 - 1978
WINDY POINT – EASTBOURNE
Photographer unknown
Spencer Logan and his wife Diane will talk about the commissioning of their first new home, its design, construction, the cleaning of thousands of bricks, and living in this unique collection of a pair of recycled brick towers with timber clad ‘saddlebags’. 
ROSS, CUSHLA and TESS JAMIESON
1974 - 1978
MAHINA BAY
Ross and Cushla have lived in their home on the Eastern hills above Mahina Bay for 48 years. They will, along with their youngest daughter, recount their experiences of working with Ian Athfield in the commissioning of the design of their home, the construction process and then living in this hillside hugging collection of building, and how this home may have influenced their living and the raising of a family of four children.
JONATHAN CUSTANCE   - THE CUSTANCE HOUSE 1981 – 1982
HAVELOCK NORTH
“The Custance House replaced an early modern home that burnt to the ground in 1981 leaving only the swimming pool unscathed.  Ray and Ann Custance, who were friends of the Athfields, sought a bold replacement.  With their son, industrial and interior designer Jonathan Custance, they prepared a four page brief for a new building….. “
Text taken from Athfield Architects by Julia Gatley 2012 AUP.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. 
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when registering for Architect tickets

description:
Tartan Up The Green, Tartan Up The Green
Gather up the clan and join us here at Brewtown Upper Hutt – Tartan Up The Green is back for 2025!

Are you ready to be blown away by the power of the Pipes and Drums as Tartan Up The Green returns this October 4th for another rousing rendition of Bagpiping, Highland Drumming and Dancing!

Our mates from RNZPBA Wellington Hawkes Bay are back to curate their all-new take on traditional pipe and drum comps with some of the finest musicians in the country.

Join us on The Greenspace for our very own family friendly, FREE to attend salute to those earth-shaking instruments of war (literally) and all things Highlands and Islands!

It won’t just be Pipers and Drummers competing for glory. Brewtown is delighted to welcome some bonnie boogying in the form of Scottish Highland Dancing, as dancers from up and down the country wow the crowd with traditional dance.

A true showcase of strength and stamina, Highland Dancing is highly technical and recognised as a sport by the Sport Council of Scotland…waltzing this aint!

So, get behind these incredible young athletes and show your support at this years Tartan Up The Green!

description:
The Lot Fundraiser Pub Quiz, Join us for a fun night of trivia and drinks at The Lot fundraiser Pub Quiz - let's raise some money together!

We are a bunch of Maessey University students and we need you help to fund our third year student film The Lot.

The film follows Riley and her boyfriend Jay, as they attempt to purchase snacks for a party. However, their arrogance and lack of communication turns a simple task into the unraveling of their relationship.
The film is a comical narrative that pokes fun at miscommunication and microaggression, and ends (literally) in a big mess. I hope audiences are able to share a laugh and see a bit of themselves in the characters: whether it’s the cashier who’s just trying to make it through his shift, or the partner who’s completely had it with their relationship.

description:
Tram 17 Inauguration (Fathers Day 2025), Join us at the Wellington Tramway Museum as we put our latest restoration project into active service at the museum!
Tram 17 was built in 1904 by the Wellington City Council Tramways as a four wheeled box (Palace) style tram. By 1917 the system had grown and 17 was rebuilt into its current form adding a set of trucks converting the tram to 8 wheels. Tram tram saw regular service until the 1940’s where it was eventually use for peak time travel, before being withdrawn in the late 50’s.
It was then sold, and taken to Bell road in Raumati on the Kapiti coast where it served as a beach hutt until the 80’s where it was donated to the Wellington tramway museum for display and eventual restoration.
2014 a conservation and restoration plan was put together, and the tram was shipped out to the Wheelwright Shop in the Wairarapa for a full body overhaul. It was transported back to the museum in 2017 and put on public display until new trucks (wheelsets) could be manufacturedby A&G price in Thames.
Since 2019 the tram has undergone new wiring, and extensive testing and running in and is now ready to take passengers along our museum.
Tram 17 is a wonderful achievement by all
Those involved, and we cannot wait to welcome you this Father’s Day to enjoy a ride on this heritage tram, saved from the scrap heap, and then saved again from rotting away.
Please note: We intend to run tram 17, however due to the nature and style of the tram, its operation is weather dependent. If we deem that the tram cannot run, we will advise accordingly.

description:
WSKN Christmas Event / SKISL, WSKN Christmas Event / SKISL
Hi everyone - welcome to the WSKN Christmas SKISL / Paddle to Mana!

On Saturday 13th December we will have a Christmas event on Mana Island, departing Titahi Bay at 10am (so arriving at 9:30) getting to Mana around 10:40, keen ones can do stuff prior to lunch around 12:00, then there might be groups that head back at different time slots, but we can work that out on the day. Return could therefore either be 1:30 or 2:30 with the latest return to Titahi Bay being 3pm.

We've made this event later than the normal SKISL so that it's easier for folks to drive down from Palmerston North, and also because it is a lunch event.

The lawn on Mana is really nice, sheltered and pleasant and there are also good walks. Mana is of course a sanctuary so you must check your boats for any wildlife especially ants that may have gotten in past the hatches. Also we cannot have any fires

Plan B: If weather nukes Mana, we'll try for Green Point or Onehunga Bay in Whitireia Park by driving there.

Plan C: We will postpone to 21 December

Also check out other Workshops in Porirua.

description:
Whāia te mātauranga hei oranga mō koutou: A Review, Nau mai, haere mai, hoki mai.
Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum is proud to present the Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum Legal Series, an informative lecture series about the purpose, historical significance and ongoing mahi of the Waitangi Tribunal held alongside the exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The Government recently announced a review of the Treaty of Waitangi Act 1975, which comes as the statute approaches its 50-year milestone on 10th October. The review is part of the coalition agreement between New Zealand First and National and will be led by an Independent Technical Advisory Group (ITAG), supported by Te Puni Kōkiri, to examine the whether the Waitangi Tribunal is “fit for purpose, not just for today, but for the generations to come.”
Joining us to discuss the topic of reform are Former Attorney-General and Treaty Minister Christopher Finlayson, and Matanuku Mahuika, who co-chaired the Waitangi Tribunal’s own Strategic Direction Review Group in 2024.
Tickets are $35 per session, or $25 for students and SuperGold Card holders, and include one drink and light kai. Doors open 5:30pm. The exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata will remain open to view until 8pm.
Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum
Wednesday 20 August | 6pm–8pm
Tickets $25–$35
This series has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
Speakers:
Christopher Finlayson
The Hon. Christopher Finlayson served as an MP for 12 years, including as Attorney-General and Minister for Treaty of Waitangi Negotiations from 2008 to 2017. During his Ministerial career he also held a number of other portfolios. He is the co-author of He Kupu Taurangi: Treaty Settlements and the Future of Aotearoa New Zealand. He left politics in 2019 and now works for Bankside Chambers as a barrister.
Matanuku Mahuika
(Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Raukawa)
Matanuku Mahuika is one of Aotearoa’s leading Māori lawyers in private practice. He co-founded Kāhui Legal in 2003. Prior to establishing Kāhui Legal, Matanuku was a partner at Walters Williams & Co and in-house counsel at the Treaty of Waitangi Fisheries Commission.
This series has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

description:
Women’s Day of Action - Taitoko Levin, Women’s Day of Action - Taitoko Levin
Women’s Day of Action: Celebrating the women in our lives!

RSVP here: https://www.together.org.nz/wdoa_levin

132 years and one day after women secured the right to vote in Aotearoa, we are gathering again in strength and solidarity.

The Government gutted Pay Equity legislation that would have eased the cost of living and lifted pay of 182,000+ people. Across Aotearoa there will be activations to send a clear message: Pay equity is not optional. Our livelihoods should never be on the political chopping block.

Join us for a community friendly event for the whole family. There will be speeches from community leaders, kai, stalls, health checks and more!

When:11am-2pm
Where: Taitoko Levin Village Green - Corner of Queen and Salisbury Streets, Levin, Levin 5510

Wear: purple, green and white in honour of suffrage

Everyone is welcome – bring your whānau, friends and community 💜💚🤍

description:
s Wellington Theatre Tours, General Admission OnlyAll Tickets are Mobile Ticket Only. 
Mobile Tickets are like Print-at-Home tickets but instead of having to print off the tickets yourself, you can just show the barcode on your mobile phone. It is the easiest way to access tickets to your events. For more information visit Ticketmaster.co.nz/mobileticket

Join us for a behind-the-scenes tour of Wellington's iconic St James Theatre and The Opera House. Discover hidden stories, architectural splendour, and rich theatrical history as you step behind the velvet curtain and explore two of the city's most beloved performance spaces. Led by expert guides, this tour takes you on a journey through over a century of theatre magic. Tread the boards in the footsteps of legendary performers. Uncover the secrets of stagecraft and marvel at the breathtaking details of these heritage-listed buildings. From opulent foyers and ornate auditoriums to backstage corridors brimming with history, you'll see the theatres as you've never seen them before.

Maybe you’ve got a library enquiry or need help with research — we’re here to help!

🕒 No bookings needed — first in, first served.
⏱️ 15-minute sessions available.

Need more time?

description:
2025 Annual South Coast Cleanup, Welcome to the 16th annual South Coast Cleanup, 10:30AM-12:00PM 13th September 2025.
As well as caring for our coasts and oceans, it’s all about community! Join us at any of our cleanup locations for a morning of litter collection and family fun.

WHEN
We kick off at 10:30am on the 13 September. We host clean up sites at 12 locations between Owhiro Bay to Breaker Bay on the Wellington South Coast. All rubbish will be gathered up around 12.15pm and taken to Lyall Bay by the playground to form one huge rubbish mountain that will be collected by the council.

Pitch in for a rubbish pile up at 12:30 at Lyall Bay playground where we will mound up our rubbish and admire our collective efforts! Then we will head to Parrotdog for a drink / kai after!

WHERE
Our fantastic friendly volunteer groups will be scattered along the coastline between Owhiro Bay and Breaker Bay. You can turn up at any of our volunteer sites:

Site 1 - Owhiro Bay hosted by Project Jonah
Site 2 - Dive Wellington hosted by Dive Wellington
Site 3 - Island Bay West hosted by Mountains to Sea and Island Bay Residents Association
Site 4 - Island Bay Snorkel Trail hosted by Friends of Taputeranga
Site 5 - Houghton Bay hosted by Houghton Valley School
Site 6 - Te Raekkaihau Point hosted by Ghost Diving
Site 7 - Lyall Bay West hosted by Underwater Club Wellington
Site 8 - Lyall Bay Central hosted by Lyall Bay Coastal Care
Site 9 - Lyall Bay East hosted by Earth Science NZ (formerly NIWA)
Site 10 - Moa Point hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 11 - Tarakena Bay hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 12 - Breaker Bay hosted by Breaker Bay Residents Association

description:
Artistic Potential: Marine Reserves - A presentation/talk, A presentation and talk facilitated by Katy Cottrell, Matteo Collina and Alice Rogers.
Marine Reserves have obvious benefits to the environment, protecting species and providing underwater appeal to snorkelers and divers but a little realised benefit is what they can offer to artists of all mediums. Join artist Katy Cottrell as she chats with academic researcher Matteo Collina and director of the Victoria University Coastal Ecology Lab – Alice Rogers. Alice and Matteo will talk about their work with marine reserves from a scientific perspective and how this has inspired the artworks by Katy Cottrell and Rick Allender for their exhibition Taputeranga: Above and Below.

We'll spend roughly an hour on the streets and waterfront with our litter pickers making our community a waste-free zone.
Pop along to Te Aro Zero Waste at Sustainability Trust HQ @ 12pm and do your bit to help make Welly waste-free. We will provide everyone with litter pickers, gloves and buckets.

description:
Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa, Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

description:
Clean and Care: Green Cleaning, Discover a more sustainable way to clean and care for your home!

Join eco-lifestylist Stella Carruthers for this hands-on workshop teaching you how to clean with no chemicals. Become aware of the dangers of greenwashing and how to identify commercial products that are safe for both people and planet.

Learn how to make your own effective cleaning solutions using simple ingredients from your kitchen. Discover that cleaning green not only saves you money, it can also support sustainable action that starts right in your home.

Please bring 2 small bottles and 1 container to take away samples of products. These can be upcycled items such as hummus pottles and small soda bottles for containers.

Spaces are limited, book now to clean green this spring!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Community Planting Belmont Regional Park, Help us reforest the hills of Belmont Regional Park. By planting native trees and shrubs, we will restore the native ngahere/forests and create an ecological corridor for wildlife to travel between Wellington, Porirua, Kāpiti and the Hutt Valley.

We have partnered with GWRC, PCC, and local iwi to restore the hills of Belmont Park. Starting on the west hillside, our aim this year is to plant 5,000 native plants to create a forest for the future! This project aims to bring the community together to restore the hillsides of the Belmont Regional Park.

We provide all the tools and training, no prior experience needed. We can even provide transport to the site. Just bring your energy and lunch. We will provide you with a yummy morning tea.

Come have some fun planting with us and TAKE ACTION FOR NATURE!

This event is part of Conservation Week 2025 - www.doc.govt.nz/conservationweek

Sign up for this event on our website ConservationVolunteers.co.nz or email Wellington@cvnz.org.nz
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Underwater Forests of Wellington, Towering seaweed forests and colourful sponge gardens lie just beneath the surface of Wellington’s coastline. Like forests on land, these underwater habitats support a remarkable diversity of life, including treasured kaimoana species. Yet they face growing pressure from human activity and environmental change.
Dr Nicole Miller will take us on a visual journey through Wellington’s Blue Belt, exploring current conservation successes and challenges. Drawing on years of diving, photography and local restoration work, Nicole will highlight the beauty and fragility of these ecosystems and why it’s more important than ever to bring changes to the surface.
This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6:00pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.
Nicole’s seaweed artworks will be on display at Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne from 1 August to 30 September, with all profits supporting Explore Your Coast: www.exploreyourcoast.co.nz/docu.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Conservation Week, Skink and Gecko Live Show Reino Grundling will talk and show slides illustrating the mostly unrealised role that lizards (skinks and geckos) had in our pristine ecosystems, with some 130 or more different species! And what makes this presentation so marvellous is that he will have a number of living examples there for all to see! Great for the kids!

Conservation Colouring Competition The Masterton Library is celebrating the importance of conservation with a colouring competition—and there are some great prizes up for grabs. There will also be an informative display featuring conservation-themed resources you’re welcome to take home with you.

Dr Marie Doole Biodiversity Funding Talk Dr Marie Doole will discuss the pros and cons around nature/biodiversity credits, an emerging option for funding the protection of biodiversity, particularly on private land, by investors, whether corporate or philanthropic. Worth attending if you've been following the media hype.

Think Like a Forest Film Forest and Bird are showing this film, starring Sam the Trap Man, in three locations. The Regent have generously offered to show it where it will have the most effect—on the big screen! The film is produced by Pure Advantage who have an aspirational programme around landscape-scale restoration of native forests called Recloaking Papatūānuku.

Kōkako Morning Hikoi Join us for a special one-off tour and experience the magic of the kōkako at Pūkaha. Follow our expert guide to a kōkako hotspot and enjoy the rare opportunity to possibly see and hear kōkako. After your walk, return to the centre for a hot drink and morning tea.

Waihinga Bridge Planting Morning Ruamāhanga Farm Foundation is hosting a morning of planting and a celebration of children's voices at the start of the soon to be opened Waihinga Bridge Walkway. Tools will be provided and all ages and abilities are welcome!

Exploring Ngahere Under Story and Campfire Talk The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective (TGCAC) takes up temporary residency at Te Whare Whakapapa Raranga to explore human-centred warning systems and ngahere's role in mitigating danger. Join us in bringing the understory into te whare through kōrero and creative exploration.

description:
Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures, Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures
📅 Wednesday, 1 October 2025
🕔 5:00–7:30 PM (Networking from 5:00 PM | Panels 5:30–7:30 PM)
📍 Te Aro Campus, Faculty of Architecture and Design Innovation, Victoria University of Wellington (139 Vivian Street)
The built environment is at the heart of Aotearoa’s response to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs). The way we plan, design, and construct our cities influences how we live — and how we tackle challenges such as climate change (SDG 13), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), affordable housing and equity (SDG 10),
responsible consumption and production (SDG 12), and partnerships for action (SDG 17).
This event is part of SDG Action Month 2025, a global campaign that highlights how communities, institutions, and industries are accelerating progress toward the 2030 Agenda.
For Aotearoa, the conversation is urgent: how can planning, design, and construction shape a sustainable, equitable, and climate-resilient future?
The evening will open with a keynote address that sets the stage with global perspectives on sustainability and the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs.
Two panels will then explore critical themes:
• Planning + Place + People — equity, housing futures, cultural identity, indigenous leadership, and policy alignment.
• Materials + Methods + Innovation—construction technology, green standards, digital tools, and carbon-conscious practice.
Alongside the discussions, attendees can view a Student Showcase from the School of Architecture and the School of Design Innovation, and contribute to a Blueprint Wall by writing their own pledges on SDG Commitment Cards, ensuring the event concludes with collective action as well as ideas.
📌 Free to attend | Open to all | RSVP required
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify Wellington: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Wellington will show you how.  
Most Wellington homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Wellington has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Wellington.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Wellington is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify the Hutt Expo 2025, The Electrify the Hutt Expo is charging into Lower Hutt with a mission to spark inspiration and supercharge your lifestyle with the power of clean electricity. As energy bills climb and climate concerns grow, this high-energy event will show you how to take control—cut costs, slash emissions, and embrace a smarter, more sustainable way of living.
Discover the incredible potential of generating your own local power through solar panels, micro wind turbines, and more. With dynamic demos, interactive exhibits, and expert talks, you'll learn how easy and empowering it is to electrify your home, reduce your reliance on fossil fuels, and enjoy the long-term benefits of clean energy.
But that’s just the beginning. The expo goes beyond saving money and helping the planet—it’s about building stronger, more resilient communities. By embracing local energy generation, we can protect ourselves from rising energy costs, power outages, and climate extremes. It’s about creating homes and neighbourhoods that are not just efficient, but future-proof.
So whether you're a curious homeowner, a savvy business owner, or just someone who wants to be part of something positive, Electrify the Hutt is your place to plug in. Come connect with experts, explore cutting-edge tech, and join a growing movement to electrify our lives and build a cleaner, brighter Hutt Valley for everyone.
Add the date to your calendar now!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Forest & Bird: Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail, Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail

Book your place now to reserve a chair.

Between November 2023 and March 2024, Te Papa natural history curator Dr Colin Miskelly walked the length of Aotearoa New Zealand on Te Araroa Trail – counting every bird seen or heard along the way. His talk will cover some of the logistics of walking the trail, as well as a summary of the birds encountered. This included looking at what difference (if any) predator trapping had on the abundance of native birds. For a taste of what the talk will cover, see Te Araroa Trail | Te Papa’s Blog.

Colin Miskelly on Mt Crawford, Tararua Ranges:
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Fundraiser - Seaweed and Ocean-inspired Art Sale at the South Coast Arts Trail, Purchase ocean-inspired art and support marine conservation!
Seaweed and ocean-inspired artworks by Explore Your Coast Founder Nicole Miller will be on show at the 2025 South Coast Arts Trail in Island Bay, 13 & 14 September 2025 (10am to 4pm).
Nicole will be at the Presbyterian Church both days with the immersive 360° video tours of Wellington's Blue Belt and Taputeranga Marine Reserve. Come along, experience Wellington's underwater world, and be inspired to dive into our local marine reserve!
All profits from artworks sold support the marine conservation and outreach initiatives of Explore Your Coast.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026, Kia ora!
Electricity and electrification are seen as the significant enablers for decarbonisation of our nation. The Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) | Te Whatunga Hiko programme aspires to meet the challenges the electrical power system will face as we journey towards sustainable decarbonisation.
Our vision is to provide an infrastructure paradigm through a hybrid AC/DC transmission and distribution system that meets the needs of tomorrow’s efficient, low-carbon, reliable and resilient electrical power system.
Funded as part of the New Zealand Government’s Strategic Science Investment Fund (SSIF) on Advanced Energy Technology Platform (AETP), the research team is investigating what the future electrical power system might look like.
Hear about the team’s latest achievements as we approach the final phase of the programme.
Attendance is in person at Victoria University Wellington.
Ngā mihi nui,
Prof. Neville Watson,
Science Leader
The detailed programme will be circulated closer to the event.
 More information on the research can be found at https://www.fan.ac.nz/
If you have any questions, please contact futurearchitecturenetwork@canterbury.ac.nz
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.
Why attend?
Learn about climate diplomacy in action
Engage with leaders shaping global climate responses
Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting
🗓️ Date: Tuesday, 26 August 2025
🕔 Time: 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM
📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington
🎟️ RSVP Required – Limited Spaces
Networking Reception: From 6:30 pm with canapes and drinks kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.

Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.

description:
Hātaitai Spring Seed Swap, Keen to get your garden going?
Come along Sat 6 Sept to swap any seeds you don’t need and get a start on the spring planting season.
Don’t know when or how best to sow your seeds? We can show you and get you going!
As always there will be some free tea and coffee (sponsored by Peoples Coffee), maybe even some home baking too!
Bring any:
Spare seeds
Seedlings (aren’t you keen!)
Spare potting mix
Spare seedling trays
Based on a Crop Swap these events aim to connect the community and reduce food & produce waste, and encourage sustainable practices.
WHAT IS CROP SWAP?
It is a wonderful welcoming monthly community gathering to share the abundance from our kitchens and gardens!
Been madly making chutney? Silver beet going crazy? Been collecting flower seeds? Got some foraged berries or a delicious cake to share?
Come along for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along. Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share.
You can find us upstairs at the Hataitai Bowling Club, 157 Hataitai Rd. We gather from 12pm with the event / swap part kicking off at 12:30pm SEE YOU THERE!
(Thanks @CropSwapTeWhanganuiaTara for support and ideas!)
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Just Sew - Repair Cafe, Repairing rather than buying is a great way to take climate action in your own life - and learn new skills along the way!
Book below and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight items for repair to our September Just Sew!
Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with repairs such as missing buttons, tears, holes and hemming. We will supply a selection of patches and buttons, but you are also welcome to bring your own if you have something specific in mind.

description:
Kai Sovereignty - Parihaka's Maara Kai and Growing for Communities, Climate and Community Activist Tuhi-ao Bailey will talk about Parihaka’s steps towards kai sovereignty, their award winning māra kai and planning a papakāinga to be resilient in the face of Climate Change.
This will be followed by an action-focused discussion led by chef and grower Mara Masarotti on how to connect urban growers with spaces to grow kai at scale.

Kid Friendly!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Lunch & Learn with David Trubridge, Join us for a very special Teulo Lunch & Learn, where design, sustainability, and community regeneration come together.
Hosted by Häfele and Teulo, this intimate event features internationally renowned designer David Trubridge and the global launch of his newest portable light: Dusk.
Enjoy lunch and conversation with peers from across the design and construction industry, with MC DK guiding the session.
What to Expect
Keynote: Think Like a Tree
In his 20-minute talk on biophilic design, David Trubridge shares how we can learn from trees and forests to design healthier, more sustainable spaces.
Film Screening: Think Like a Forest
This short film from Pure Advantage highlights the Recloaking Papatūānuku movement, an ambitious initiative to restore more than 2 million hectares of native forest and wetland in Aotearoa. Featuring Sam the Trap Man and local kaitiaki, it’s both an inspiration and a call to action.
Global Launch: The Dusk Lamp
Be among the first to experience Dusk, David’s most portable light yet, inspired by his collaboration with Pure Salt’s Tamatea Art Project in Fiordland. A new short documentary will showcase the story behind the design and the environmental partnership that shaped it. A portion of all sales will support Pure Salt’s conservation efforts in Dusky Sound.
Local Conservation Panel
Hear from organisations leading vital regeneration work, including the Maraetōtara Tree Trust, Esk River planting projects, and Te Mata Peak Park restoration, and learn how you can get involved.
Why Attend?
This Lunch & Learn is more than a product launch or film screening — it’s a chance to connect with the design community, hear from one of New Zealand’s most iconic designers, and explore practical steps toward a regenerative future.

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Permaculture for People & Place, Permaculture for People & Place
🌱 Permaculture for People & Place - New Workshop at Mangaroa Farms. Led by our resident permaculture enthusiast Halina Horn, experience a hands-on learning journey for the whole whānau. Come get your hands in the soil, explore the garden, and grow over a 4 week course alongside your tamariki 🌻

Together, we’ll learn to care for land, food, and each other. We’ll achieve this through learning about permaculture systems, composting, water wisdom, nature play, and storytelling.

This event is friendly for kids and adults alike - a great opportunity to get family connection over earth-based practices going.

HOW IT WORKS:
🌀 Sign up for 4 x Saturdays in Nov (1st, 8th, 15th, 22nd) at the link below.

🕙 Each event runs from 10am – 1pm | 298 Whitemans Valley road, Upper Hutt

👦 For families, educators, grandparents, & curious growers (ages 5+)

💚 Different adults and kids ticket options available

This is the first of many permaculture education seasonal offerings designed to re-root us in the rhythms of nature.

The second block course in November will cover key themes in seeds, soil, spring growth, plant communities and more... so come along to continue the learning journey.

Spots are limited. Come and grow with us.

description:
Resilience and Emissions Reduction Workshop for Not-For-Profits | Blenheim, Ready your not-for-profit for the future
Do you know you need to take action to address climate change but don’t know where to start?
Do you want to strengthen your organisations’ planning and readiness for change?
Do you want practical tools and support to measure, assess, and report on your organisations’ impact?

In partnership with Rātā Foundation, our Earth+ Resilience and Emissions Reduction programme has been designed to flip the script on climate change, centering your organisation as agents of change and kitting you with the tools, support and community to make a difference; and it’s free of charge!
About the programme
With the support of the Terra Nova team and other programme participants, you will be guided to identify how your organisation is uniquely placed to contribute to the resilience and wellbeing of people and planet, and the opportunities and obstacles to creating positive change.
The programme is accessible and suitable for everyone, from those just starting on the journey, to those who have steps in place but are looking to gain access to further resources. This programme is not intended to add extra workload or deliverables for your organisation, it is an offer of support to integrate an Earth+ approach into your BAU; an answer to the question “what can we do about climate change?”
We know that every organisation’s capacity is different, so our support is available for you to utilise it when you need it until the end of 2025. This includes:
Access to a dedicated online community where you can connect with the Terra Nova team, other Rātā grantees and specialised partners. Ask questions, find resources and share your journey.
A toolkit of resources and impact sessions to develop your knowledge and connect you with the expertise and support to build resilience and tackle change in a range of impact areas.
Complementary access to the Cogo carbon emissions measurement tool, providing you the ability to quantify and report on your emissions impact and providing recommended actions for emissions reduction and cost savings, in an easy-to-use format.
It begins with a 1-day interactive workshop to kick things off. By the end of the workshop, you will walk away:
Feeling more empowered about the future, with a deeper understanding of resilience and climate change as it relates to your organisation’s context.
Having explored how you can make change positive and achievable, centered on the needs of your community and team. 
With free access to Cogo carbon manager, an emissions profile, report of your carbon footprint and practical action you can take to reduce your emissions.
Having built a network of support and gained free-to-use practical tools and templates.
Note: we will be running multiple workshops throughout the year; you only need to attend one workshop to join the programme. If you prefer an alternate date, please head to our Humanitix profile to find the corresponding event. 
The programme is fully funded for not-for-profit organisations and registrations are now open for 2025! Register for the programme and secure your spot in a workshop through this Humanatix event, and a member of the Terra Nova team will be in touch to confirm your enrollment. For more information about the programme and workshop, visit the Terra Nova website.
We look forward to welcoming you into our community of changemakers!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Resilient Waters: NZ–German Conference, Strengthening Urban Water Systems Against Extreme Weather – German Insights for Aotearoa

New Zealand’s water infrastructure is under growing pressure from climate change, ageing systems, and extreme weather events. Ensuring safe drinking water, reliable wastewater management, and resilient infrastructure requires fresh thinking and innovative solutions.
The Resilient Waters Conference, hosted by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC), will bring together German innovators and New Zealand stakeholders for a high-level forum dedicated to future-proofing New Zealand’s water systems.
At this conference, a delegation of German companies will present cutting-edge technologies and intelligent system solutions designed to improve water resilience in the face of climate change. The programme will feature expert presentations, sector-specific insights, and networking opportunities with a professional audience from water utilities, engineering firms, city councils, and decision-making bodies.
Following the conference, the programme for the delegation will continue with B2B meetings, expert roundtables, and site visits in Wellington, Hawke’s Bay, and Auckland from 17–21 November 2025. These tailored sessions will connect German companies directly with New Zealand stakeholders to exchange knowledge, explore collaboration, and identify concrete opportunities for partnership.
 This initiative is organised by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC) in collaboration with German partner AHP International and funded by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWE).

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we look forward to a day of planting, learning and creativity at Ruamāhanga Farm. Just outside Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are bringing the local community together to help restore wetlands and provide greater access to the awa. The restoration is a foundation for Te Reo o te Wai, an arts and conservation programme for local primary schools.


Our hosts Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will share the story of the land and the conversion of a traditional stock and crop farm into a regenerative, community oriented venture. They will involve us in some of the experiential ways they are helping children and young people connect to hidden places along the Ruamāhanga. The day will include planting trees and grasses along a new wetland walk combined with nature based story telling, art and creative writing. We will have a shared lunch by the awa or under canvas if it is wet.

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms, Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms
Our native riparian plantings from 2023 have really started to thrive this winter, visible as you drive past the farm, or walking the local farm trail loop.

These native seedlings planted alongside the river, act like living sponges, slowing any farm runoff, filtering nutrients, anchoring soil and shading the water so that beneficial invertebrates & life forms can thrive. Creating cleaner water, richer habitat and less flooding downstream.

Keen to get involved? We have a few tree planting events coming up this season:

🌳 TREE PLANTING DAYS
- Sat 16th Aug 10am - 3pm
- Sat 6th Sep 10am - 3pm with @forestandbirdwellington

EVENT DETAILS
- Meet at 10am, 298 Whitemans Valley Road, Upper Hutt.
- We will walk 5-10mins to our planting site near te Awa o Mangaroa / the Mangaroa river.
- Come for a short time, or a long time, and join us for a kai and refreshments at 2pm after the mahi is complete.

BRING WITH YOU
- A Jacket and warm clothes - be prepared for a range of weather
- Boots or stout shoes
- Gloves - if you have them
- A spade if you have one
- Water bottle

Register at https://store.mangaroa.org/collections/events

#treeplanting #mangaroafarms #riparianplanting #nativetrees #volunteer #alwaysbeplanting

description:
WECG ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING 2025, ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
Tena Tatou Katoa, Greetings Everyone
A WARM INVITATION TO ALL TO ATTEND THE 2025 AGM OF THE WAIKANAE ESTUARY CARE GROUP INC
Venue: The Otaihanga Boating Club, Makora Rd,
Otaihanga
Date & time: Wednesday 3rd September at 7pm
Speaker Mike Joy - see Bio below

Mike is a Senior Research Fellow and Lecturer in Environmental Science at the School of Geography, Environment and Earth Sciences, Mike’s research includes ecological modelling, freshwater bioassessment, environmental policy, biophysical limits to growth and the role of energy in society. He is publicly outspoken about the decline in freshwater quality and ecosystems, especially the impact of nutrient pollution from intensive dairying on New Zealand's "100% Pure", clean, green image.
Mike is an outspoken advocate for environmental protection in New Zealand and for this has received several awards including an Ecology in Action award from the NZ Ecological Society, the Charles Fleming Award for environmental achievement in 2013 and in 2023 the Callaghan Medal for science communication from the Royal Society of New Zealand. In 2015 he was awarded the Morgan Foundation inaugural River Voice Award and in 2017 the inaugural NZ Universities Critic and Conscience award. His book 'The Fight for Freshwater' is a memoir that provides a rare first hand look at those whose voices question the health and future of our waterways.
The Meeting will conclude with supper and korero

description:
Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
