description:
6-12 In person PLD, 6-12 In person PLD
The story of Communication and Signs is one of the five great stories which scaffold the learning in Montessori classrooms for the 6-12 year old child. It traces the beginnings of human communication and the development of writing.

How can we as educators encourage writing in our Montessori environments and ensure collaborations and an understanding of the basic writing processes, bring success and enthusiasm to the telling of powerful stories?

What are some of the stumbling blocks for children when researching? How can we provide strategies and structure to enable lively and informative information writing?

In this day-long face to face workshop, with a focus on guidance for narrative and information writing, participants will be invited into the world of learning to write. Strategies and exercises to stimulate interest and action for writers will be given, alongside challenges and advanced crafting lessons for more fluent writers in 6-9 and 9-12 classrooms. We will examine elements of structuring, elaboration, character and place, revision, and author techniques. Note taking and writing for research will be included in an information writing session.

Day 2: Sunday 14th September
Come prepared to share your collective wisdom while we align NZC History curriculum to what we do in our classrooms to ensure that everything is covered. By September we will also have a better idea of where the conventional system is headed with the new-look maths coming out. We will spend time unpacking the the WHY we do what we do.

This is an opportunity for you to discuss, share ideas and gain ideas for ways forward.

Also check out other Arts events in Wellington, Literary Art events in Wellington, Workshops in Wellington.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Ask an Astrobiologist, Are we alone in the Universe?  Ask a NASA astrobiologist! 
Event Overview
In 2025, we mark a decade of astrobiology in Aotearoa New Zealand—a field of science that asks the biggest questions of all:
How did life begin?
Are we alone in the Universe?
What is our future beyond Earth?
We also mark 150 years of US-NZ scientific partnership. What better way to honour these two milestones than with a public talk by three eminent NASA astrobiologists and science communicators!
Join Dr Sanjoy Som, Dr Graham Lau, and Sarah Marcotte as they tell us about exciting current developments in astrobiology, plus get a chance to ask YOUR burning questions about life, aliens and the Solar System. 
Guest Speakers
🔹 Dr Graham Lau – “The Cosmobiologist”
Dr. Graham Lau, “the Cosmobiologist,” is an astrobiologist, science communicator, and host of NASA’s Ask an Astrobiologist. As Director of Communications at Blue Marble Space, he blends research, outreach, and education, inspiring global audiences. His Arctic geomicrobiology work informs life-detection strategies for Mars, Europa, and beyond.  
🔹 Dr Sanjoy Som
Dr. Sanjoy Som, planetary scientist and founder of the Blue Marble Science Institute of Science, studies planetary environments from early Earth to Mars. His work combines geochemistry, field expeditions, and science communication, fostering global partnerships in astrobiology while inspiring public engagement with the science of planetary habitability.  
🔹 Sarah Marcotte
Sarah Marcotte is NASA STEM Engagement Network lead at JPL, managing the Solar System Ambassadors Program. A specialist in Mars and planetary mission outreach, she makes complex space science engaging for public audiences through events, media, and educational programs.  
Proudly Presented By
New Zealand Astrobiology Network (NZAN)
Victoria University of Wellington
SpacewardBound New Zealand
With generous support from the US Embassy in New Zealand
🎟️ Reserve your seat now and be part of the conversation about life in the Universe!

description:
Café Scientifique - Space: What Is Our Place In the Cosmos?, Join us for a new Café Scientifique series hosted by Pūtaiao ki te Pāpori—School of Science in Society.

Café Scientifique is a place where, for the price of a cup of coffee or a glass of wine, anyone can come to explore the latest ideas in science and technology in a relaxed, friendly environment.

Doors open at 5.30 pm, talks begin at 6 pm. All welcome—free entry, nibbles provided.

Please note: anyone under the age of 18 must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
For further information, please contact scienceinsociety@vuw.ac.nz.

description:
Data Governance in the Pacific - Challenges and Opportunities, Our Data Governance Wellington events tend to focus on the great work, challenges and opportunities members have experienced in their own organisations around Wellington and New Zealand. However, this time we are very lucky to have a presentation from two members of the Pacific Community (SPC) that add an international dimension to our data governance conversations.
This talk will spotlight unique Pacific experiences—building federated data ecosystems, navigating data sovereignty, and fostering cross-regional collaboration—while drawing connections and insights that may be relevant to New Zealand’s own data governance community.
Our speakers for this event are:
Malcolm Fraser - Malcolm is a data governance and digital innovation specialist focused on unlocking the value of data across public, private, and social sectors. Currently leading the Pacific Data Hub Team at Pacific Community (SPC), based in New Caledonia, he is committed to advancing ethical data practices and building integrated data ecosystems that benefit society, the environment, and the economy.
Kevin Sweeney - Kevin is the Data Governance Advisor for SPC – Pacific Community, the preeminent international development organisation for the Pacific. He is currently leading an initiative to implement and improve Data Governance within SPC, across its Pacific Island nation members, and amongst its international partners. Prior to joining SPC, Kevin served as the Principal Advisor for the Data System Leadership branch of Stats NZ, advising the Government Chief Data Steward, helping strengthen data capability across the government data system, while serving as the New Zealand delegate on international data forums. With several decades of experience scoping and implementing data and information strategies and systems, Kevin has worked in numerous capacities in New Zealand and the United States, including as Director of the New Zealand Geospatial Office, founding partner of a strategic consulting firm, and independently through his own management consulting practice.
Event Details
This event will be an in-person event and online.
Online
The link to the Teams meeting is here.
In Person
If you wish to attend to in person, please email emailforhugh@gmail.com to register before Wednesday the 5th of November. Pre-registering helps speed up the event! The event will be held in the Kāinga Ora offices, 7 Waterloo Quay in Wellington. Please enter at the end of the building closest to the new BNZ building and go to Level 5 where the Kāinga Ora reception is.
When registering, please OPT IN to following us so we can keep you updated of more events in the future!

description:
Hutt Valley (Upper Hutt/Lower Hutt) Mathematics Leadership Community 2025, Are you the maths lead in your school? Do you feel equipped to lead the roll out of the new mathematics and statistics curriculum? Would you like to be part of a group of like-minded leads?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.

description: Inaugural Professorial Lecture - Professor Angela Ballantyne, Inaugural Professorial Lecture "Making things right". What does it mean to make things right? Medicine and science often turn to bioethics for concrete solutions to ethical challenges. But in reality, there is rarely a single, obvious ‘right’ answer. Human systems are inherently messy, and challenged by a legacy of injustice, unequal distributions of power, and declining social trust. This talk will describe the potential for bioethics to help clarify and navigate ethics dilemmas; pragmatically inching us closer to making things – if not right, then at least – better.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene and GIB.
CPD points: 10
TIMING:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
LECTURE DATES:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre

description:
Site Visit - Holcim Readymix Wellington, Ever wondered how concrete is made?
Join us on Thursday 4th September, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of the Holcim Readymix NZ plant. Grab a behind the scenes look at:
 🏗️ The Process: How raw materials like cement, aggregates & water are mixed to create concrete
⚙️ Batching & Mixing: How mix designs are selected and adjusted
📏 Quality: Quality controls & production oversight, including testing & slumping
🚚 Dispatch:  Loading, scheduling & delivery coordination
🌱 Sustainability: Low carbon products and how Holcim is approaching driving a circular economy
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Thursday, 4th September, 1pm
📍 LOCATION: 121 Centennial Highway, Ngauranga Gorge
🚗PARKING: Parking is tricky! Please carpool if possible, limited parking is available at the front of the Holcim offices (2 car parks) and one more at the top car park. Alternatively, bus route #1 stops off at Ngauranga Gorge (Kiwi Point) stop and is a short walk away
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 10 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, glasses (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 ABOUT HOLCIM: Holcim is a global company across Europe, Asia, Pacific, Latin America, Middle East and Africa.  Holcim NZ  is a leading supplier of cement, aggregates and ready-mix concrete in New Zealand dating back to 1888. You may have noticed their big silos on the Centre Port (near the Interislander). Holcim have a network of plants throughout New Zealand, and one of their main missions is around sustainability, where they actively promote low-carbon concrete solutions, including their premium range ECOPact ECOplanet.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Steve Sinclair - public lecture, Steve Sinclair - public lecture
'fourth_space, beyond Architecture as a Narcissistic Entity'

LT2 at the School of Architecture and Design VUW.

About this Event

Steve Sinclair is co-founder and director of fourth_space, a practice that seeks to "rescue space to make places," to "recycle bits of left-over architecture," and to make Architecture as "a unifying discipline - politics, regulation, location, design, finance, construction and user experience - that should maintain social and artistic concerns."


https://cdn-az.allevents.in/events10/banners/b883d840-741c-11f0-867e-7d1fd93eb1fd-rimg-w1200-h597-dcd5d5d5-gmir.jpg

Steve studied at the Mackintosh School of Architecture and the Bartlett School before completing an MSc at the London School of Economics. He worked at Morphosis, Ron Arad Associates, FAT (Fashion Architecture Taste), and Harper Mackay (MAK), before joining Paolo Mozzato in 2004, and subsequently Huw Williams, to form fourth_space.
In addition to directing fourth_space Steve is a design advisor to the Hackney Estate Regeneration Design Group, teaches at the AA and is co-owner of award winning Ombra bar & restaurant - where the “Negroni_Talks...!” happen. Available on podcast, these events "promote looser, all-encompassing engagements with greater participation, as well as dispelling false authority and un-challengable ‘expert’ opinions.... "
Steve's lecture is hosted by Te Kāhui Whaihanga ~ New Zealand Institute of Architecture in association with School of Architecture and Design, Victoria University of Wellington ~ Te Herenga Waka and the Architectural Centre.

Also check out other Arts events in Wellington.

description:
Box of Birds, When: 20th – 26th September 2025
Monday - Saturday 10am
No shows on Sundays
Hailed as "the cutest little show in Aotearoa" (Hamilton Arts Festival 2024), award-winning theatre company Birdlife Productions have created this gorgeous theatre show designed especially for ages 4 to 9 years, Including exquisite puppetry, live interactive songs, projection and the teaching of a waiata, this work reflects our transformative connection to nature. Peter is reluctant to stay with nanna in the school holidays because she lives in the country and doesn't have a TV but Nanna finds ways to engage Peter in her love of the forest, especially the precious manu, when they build a nesting box for Ruru together. Peter is excited to see if Ruru will make her home in the box, waiting patiently while many other birds arrive to check out the box first! And after all that waiting, Nanna takes Peter on an exciting night time forest walk to find Ruru - in the dark! The bird characters are all familiar New Zealand locals, such as piwakawaka, kereru, tui and ruru, and the story highlights the importance of supporting them and the different needs they may have. Teachers and Parents have been ecstatic about this show and hundreds of New Zealand children have been transfixed by it.
As quoted by Theatreview: “This is truly a New Zealand show for New Zealand children and all those young-at-heart”.


Prices are just $15.00 per person
Under 2's are free
Special $7 preview show on Saturday September 20th 2025!

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
(door sales will be available)
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Daffodil Express 2025
Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!

Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.

Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.

Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.

The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.

Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.

Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!

The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.

Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!

Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free

For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/

description:
Glow in the dark titiwai tours - New Zealand glow worms, A fascinating tour into the world of titiwai, New Zealand's glow worms, in Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā. Meet at the Founders’ entrance to Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā on Glenmore Street. Please bring your ticket, a torch, and an umbrella if it’s raining. We'll see you there!
This tour is operated by the Friends of Wellington Botanic Garden.
Glow Worm Tour Ticket Refund Policy
• No Refunds: We do not offer refunds for Glow Worm Tour tickets.
• Ticket Transfers: If you can’t attend your booked tour, we will put you on a future tour, subject to availability. Please contact us as soon as possible to arrange this.
• Weather Conditions: Tours operate rain or shine. In the event of extreme weather or unsafe conditions, we will reschedule your tour or provide a refund.
For any changes or enquiries, please get in touch with us in advance at Treehouse@wcc.govt.nz or call 04 499 1400.

With over 400 centres across Aotearoa there is one near you. You get three free visits before enrolling, so why not try a few centres in your community to see what suits you best?

description:
Open Day at Kumutoto Forest, The Kumutoto Restoration Project is celebrating one year of restoration at the Kumutoto ngahere and awa and we would like to celebrate with you! Join us on Sunday 14 September from 10am - 2pm for a day of engaging workshops and activities!!
This is a kids-friendly day, with a childrens workstation, forbuilding and other family activities.
Workshops and acitvities include...
• Invertebrate studies
• Water testing
• Understanding fish passageways
• Stormwater networks
• Karaka berry foraging
• DIY Tracking tunnels
The day will also have a food truck and guided tours of the awa and forest trap line.
Come and celebrate the first year restoring the mauri and mana of this wāhi tūpuna urban stream and forest.

Wā Ora is the only Montessori school in New Zealand that caters for children from playgroup through to Year 13. Mark the date in your diary and pop in to see our Montessori playgroup, preschool and primary environment. Teachers and current parents will also be available to chat. description:
Read to Kurī, Join us and our doggy guests from Canine Friends Pet Therapy for Read to Kurī at the library. You can book a 15-minute session to sit with one of our friendly dogs and read your favourite book, or one you've found at the library.
Read to Kurī aims to help children improve their literacy, self-confidence, and self-esteem in a relaxed, non-judgemental environment. This programme is perfect for tamariki aged 5+ who would like to practice their reading skills while making a new canine friend at the library.
To book your session, please call the library on 04 477 6151, or email johnsonville.library@wcc.govt.nz with your preferred date and time.
Bookings are for 15 minutes only. After you have booked, library staff will be in contact informing you what time to arrive for your session.

description:
Science Bites School Holidays Science Workshops, Get hands-on with some tasty, edible science these school holidays! Science Bites is an edible science workshop for tamariki aged 8-12 years old.

Learn about rainbow diffraction chocolate, make your own gummy worms, explore some glow-in-the-dark jelly, and more! All the projects in this workshop are safe to eat, meaning kids can taste their creations as they learn.

Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!

Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.

Tamariki can be dropped-off in the morning and picked-up afterwards; caregivers are not required to stay for the duration of the workshop. Tamariki should bring a packed lunch.

This workshop will involve handling and consuming some known allergens and substances your child may be sensitive to. Please refer to the list on the Space Place website.

Best suited for children aged 8-12. $65 per tamariki - 9am-1pm.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour
Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
• No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
• Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
• Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
• Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
• Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
• Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
• Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email or call 04 499 1400.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
The Monster in the Maze, The myth of the Minotaur is a tale almost as old as storytelling itself, but with The Monster in the Maze Jonathan Dove and Alisdair Middleton have excavated rich, new life from this classic. In this brand new staging by director Anapela Polataivao (Red White and Brass, Wild Dogs Under My Skirt), this story will be told as never before.

When King Minos defeats the Athenians, he metes out his punishment in the cruellest way possible: by destroying their hope for the future. Every year, the king compels the conquered Athenians to send him their youth, to be fed to the terrible beast at the centre of his island’s maze: the Minotaur. As King Minos triumphs, his great monster “will eat your future, it will rip your hope, it will stamp your youth, your children in the sand.”

As the vindictive king will soon learn, however, these youth will not accept their fate without a fierce challenge. The Monster in the Maze is a story about resistance; about justice; about finding power not in oppression, but in collectivism. Fittingly, then, it’s also a groundbreaking work in its form: a community-focused and community-driven opera in which young and community singers and players stand proudly shoulder-to-shoulder with their professional counterparts, and in which both are integral.

The Monster in the Maze has been roundly praised by audiences, participants and reviewers worldwide, and in its Aotearoa debut season, it will serve as a gorgeous articulation of New Zealand Opera’s reciprocal community kaupapa.

Sung in English with surtitles.

description:
Water Cast Pendants Taster - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.

Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.

You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.

Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!

We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.

The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.

A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.

This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.

For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Ōtari Glow Worm Tour, Ōtari Glow Worm Tour
Take a guided night tour through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and discover some of the fascinating night-time residents on your way to see the titiwai/glowworms. Enjoy the tranquil beauty of the bush after dark and witness the magical glow of these unique creatures.

This outdoor night-time tour takes just over an hour.
If bringing children, we find it most suitable for those aged 5 years and older.
The tour requires a moderate level of fitness, the route includes numerous steps to and from the glowworms.

Meet at the Ōtari Visitors Centre, 150 Wilton Road. Bring warm clothes, walking shoes, and a torch.

This tour is operated by the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust. Join the Trust from just $20 a year and the glow worm tour is free, plus you’ll be supporting the amazing work the Trust does. Join today at owbt.nz/membership-donations/

Glow Worm Tour Ticket Refund Policy
• No Refunds: We do not offer refunds for Glow Worm Tour tickets.
• Ticket Transfers: If you can’t attend your booked tour, we will put you on a future tour, subject to availability. Please contact us as soon as possible to arrange this.
• Weather Conditions: Tours operate rain or shine. In the event of extreme weather or unsafe conditions, we will reschedule your tour or provide a refund.

For any changes or inquiries, please get in touch with us in advance at or call 04 499 1400.

“Jingle Jigs, Reels a Treat.”
Ken Longworth – The Newcastle Herald

Direct from its Off-Broadway season, A Taste of Ireland - The Irish Music & Dance Sensation, presents its holiday spectacular, A Celtic Christmas. Prepare to be enchanted with some of the world’s finest Irish dancers and musicians bringing the spirit of Christmas to life, in a show that will make you laugh, cry, and sing into the night.

After captivating audiences across the USA and around the world, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland returns to New Zealand this festive season following a highly successful 2022 tour. Experience the magic as world-class performers blend melodic folk mash-ups, acapella tap battles, and heartwarming storytelling in one truly unforgettable performance.

Featuring former World Irish dance champions and stars from Lord of the Dance and Riverdance, A Celtic Christmas delivers a holiday spectacular packed with Irish wit, traditional tunes and heartfelt ballads, alongside all your favorite carols. The show’s exciting mix of electrifying rhythms and extraordinary talent promises an evening brimming with Irish charm and enthralling entertainment, all in one powerhouse event.

Immerse yourself in a traditional Celtic landscape and let the magic of an Irish Christmas transport you to a world filled with excitement and wonder, where vibrant music and dance embody the heartbeat of the festive season.

With over one hundred and fifty 5-star Facebook reviews and over 150,000 followers, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland promises 100% live singing and dancing as it bridges the gap between energetic folk music, Irish dance, and modern tap styles.

Don’t miss your chance to see this magical show as it tours New Zealand for a strictly limited season. Get your tickets now before they sell out.

description:
A Century Celebration!, A Century Celebration!
In 1926, at a meeting at the Accounts Chambers in Johnston Street, Wellington, Mrs JW Bell (and her husband) offered to lease three sections of her land for the purposes of establishing a tennis and bowling club in Titahi Bay.

Well Mrs Bell, thanks to your kind offer, we are still here 100 years later and don’t we have some stories and memories to share of those years gone by!

Over the course of Wellington Anniversary weekend (16-18 January 2026), we invite current and former members of the Titahi Bay Tennis Club to come and join us in celebrating this incredible milestone!

In coming months, we will update this post with more information about events planned for the weekend. In the meantime, please put this in your diary, share with friends, family, or perhaps use it as an opportunity to reach out to a former interclub team mate you haven’t seen or heard from in a while and tell them you’ll see them there!

We hope you can join us for what should be a great occasion!



(article : https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19270114.2.141)

description:
Beervana, New Zealand’s boldest, hoppiest, and most delightfully weird beer festival. This is no ordinary tasting event, it’s a full-blown sensory adventure where brewers go wild, food gets fancy, and the unexpected is always on tap. 

Expect more than 60 breweries pouring over 300 unique brews—from hazy IPAs and fruited sours to beer cocktails and non-alcoholic surprises. 

But Beervana isn’t just about the beer. It’s a feast for all senses: think whitebait fritters from Boulcott St Bistro, Korean fried chicken, Mahurangi oysters. Add in live music, quirky brewery stands (yes, there’s a Best Stand vote), and unexpected entertainment and you’ve got a festival that you'll come away from with a greater knowledge of great beer, a belly full and plenty of fun memories with your mates.

description:
Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival, Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival
Wellington's annual spring cherry blossom festival is back this September 🌸 A must-see event with 350+ cherry blossom trees creating a sea of pink 🌸

⭐ 'After Dark' evening light experience tickets now on sale.

📷 Capture gram-worthy photos and videos under the blossoms, and find our viral style photo spots including a giant living love heart, a swing, a boat (new this year!), a giant frame, and more

🛏️ Book a night in our chalet accomodation and wake up to a sea of pink 🌸

☕ Pre-purchase a delightful high tea alongside your ticket for the full experience (bookings required)☕

Weekends often sell out so make sure you have pre-purchased tickets online to secure your car park as spaces are limited. We hate to have to turn cars away when tickets are sold out so please do pre-purchase your tickets this year for weekends!! 🚗

🌸 New This Year - Flexi Passes
This pass allows you to come on whichever day you like. Not sure about the weather or at what level of blossom the trees are then this is for you. Purchase this ticket and come during the day on whichever day and time you like. (These tickets do NOT cover the After Dark experience).

Shuttles are available from Wellington, Palmerston North, Masterton or (anywhere!) with Capital Shuttles. With bookings available from 1 person, up to a 54 seater bus, they are the ideal way to get to and from Aston Norwood Gardens 🚌

Our in house photographer Lilia will be back again offering affordable professional photography sessions - perfect for family photos, couple photos, solo, friend groups, or even secret engagements! 📷

🌸 Blossom Valley is more than an event—it’s a fleeting moment of beauty, peace, and connection with nature. We can’t wait to share it with you. 🌸

-
In 1994, inspired by visits to Japan, owners Mark and Fiona Rammell planted over 350 Sakura Cherry Blossoms and are now seeing their dream burst into life each Spring.

Blossom Valley is an annual spring celebration sure to put the spring in your step as you explore the 14 acres of garden with New Zealand’s highest number and density of mature cherry blossom trees in the one place. For just a short amount of time each year at Aston Norwood Gardens in Kaitoke, Upper Hutt, hundreds of cherry trees come alive creating a canopy of pink blossom.

The event is carefully scheduled around the natural blossoming of the trees, with data from previous years informing the date selection. While the team at Blossom Valley do their best to ensure the ultimate blossom experience the timing of the bloom is up to mother nature.

Iconic daffodil field | Heritage train | High Street markets | Street performers | WAI ART SHOW | Library crafts + MORE... Here's a snippet of what's in store:

Your Daffodil Flyer experience (that's the train between Carterton to Masterton) has been revamped with new one-way options! Book you seat now: https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-festival-flyer/

Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori also begins on September 14 - to celebrate we invite you to come in and browse our Māori Collection and pick up a flyer – listing 50 of our resources to help you on your te reo journey.

description:
Ecstatic Dance Wellington, Ecstatic Dance Wellington
💫 Move. Release. Connect. The first Ecstatic Dance Wellington is here — come celebrate our launch at Vogelmorn with DJ Kimba Jade on the decks. 🌙❤️

🌟✨ Ecstatic Dance Wellington – Launch Event ✨🌟

With DJ Kimba Jade @ Vogelmorn, Wellington

Kimba Jade & Bernie Cruise are thrilled to bring Ecstatic Dance Wellington to life! 🎉 This is the launch event, and we can’t wait to co-create the first of many transformational dance journeys with you.

💫 What is Ecstatic Dance?
A freeform, drug- and alcohol-free dance experience where you move however your body wants. The music flows like a wave — starting slow, rising to ecstatic peaks, then softening into stillness. It’s therapeutic, uplifting, and a powerful way to connect with yourself and community.

Please note, that this Ecstatic Dance is not verbally guided, we let the music guide you 😊. Dance freely how your body moves you.

🎶 This Dance Floor
Guided by DJ Kimba Jade, expect an immersive journey through deep bass, tribal rhythms, and global soundscapes that awaken both body and spirit. With over 24 years behind the decks—including 8 years dedicated to Ecstatic Dance—Kimba crafts transformative spaces of joy, release, and connection. Originally from Auckland, she curated Alchemic Dance Floor events for 5 years, now co-runs the Ecstatic Dance Festival, and leads Alchemic Ecstatic Dance DJ Trainings. She’s thrilled to share her magic and move with you on the dance floor!

🎶 The Sound System
Here at Ecstatic Dance Wellington, we believe in using a phat sound system with lots of bass for our dances. We will be bringing an ultra vibey and super bassy experience for you!


🗓 Event Details
📍 Vogelmorn, 13 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington
🕖 7:00pm – Opening Circle
🕢 7:15pm – Ecstatic Dance
🕘 8:45pm – Closing Circle
🕘 9:00pm – Chai & Chocolate (for those wanting to socialise)

🎟 Tickets
$25 online
https://events.humanitix.com/ecstatic-dance-wellington

$30 cash on the door

**If you would like to come but are unwaged or struggling, please send us a message directly, we'd love to help.

☀️ Extra Info
- Beanbags are provided for the end relaxation.
- Doors will open at 6.45pm for you to socialise in the lobby, we'll start promptly at 7pm.

We are very much looking forward to joining the conscious dance community in Wellington and sharing our magic.

❤️ What to Bring

Water bottle

Loose, comfy clothes

Warm layers for afterwards

A friend!

🌟 Guidelines

Drug & alcohol free event

Silence on the dance floor

No phones/cameras on the dance floor

Respect the space & each other 😊

🎧 Tune into Kimba’s ED sets:
Mixcloud: https://www.mixcloud.com/kimbajade/

✨ Come help us launch Ecstatic Dance Wellington — a night of music, movement & magic. ✨

There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. description:
Greytown Through the Ages, Greytown Through the Ages
DATE: All Weekend
LOCATION: various retail shops & eateries in Greytown Main St.
AGES: All
COST: Free
Step back in time with Greytown Through the Ages, a unique, immersive event where visitors can explore the town’s rich history simply by strolling along its charming Main Street and local shops. Participating businesses throughout Greytown will display historical photographs — some dating back as far as the 1850s.

Wander into cafés, boutiques and eateries to discover black-and-white snapshots of rarely seen archival images showing what Greytown once looked like. From dusty horse-drawn streets to early main street storefronts of eras gone by, each location offers a different window into the past.

Many photographs will be matched with the current buildings so visitors can compare then and now, sparking conversations and nostalgia and soak in the legacy of one of New Zealand’s most historic towns.

www.greytownarttown.com

Audiology Touring, Coastal Promotions & George FM present…

description:
Hutt Japan Day 2025, Hutt Japan Day 2025
Hutt Japan Day is back!
Join us for a vibrant celebration of Japanese culture at the Hutt Japan Day festival, held at the Lower Hutt Town Hall, Dowse Square & Dowse Art Gallery on Sunday, 9 November.

Celebrating 30 Years of Friendship
This year's event is extra special, marking 30 years of partnership with Minoh City, our sister city in Osaka, Japan. The festival is organised by the Hutt Minoh House Friendship Trust, with support from the Hutt City Council and the Embassy of Japan.

What’s on offer?
• Be captivated by an array of Japanese performances and demonstrations
• Engage in hands-on activities and workshops
• Immerse yourself in the exhilarating rhythms of taiko drumming
• Indulge in delectable Japanese cuisine from one of our food vendors/stalls
• Explore our market area for unique Japanese treasures

Get Involved!
To participate in this special celebration as a performer, artist, cultural group, demonstration, market or food vendor, please visit our website for more details and registration forms: https://www.huttminoh.org.nz/participate-in-hutt-japan-day-2025

Save the Date - Sunday, 9 November 2025
Lower Hutt Town Hall, Dowse Square & The Dowse Art Museum

We look forward to celebrating the richness of Japanese culture with you!

description:
Hutt Valley Annual Diwali 2025, Hutt Valley Annual Diwali 2025
The Annual Hutt Valley Diwali, organised by the Wellington Punjabi Sports and Cultural Club Inc. (WPSCC Inc.), is a vibrant, family-friendly celebration of light, culture, and community. Held each year in the heart of the Hutt Valley, this non-profit event brings together people of all ages and backgrounds to enjoy the rich traditions of Diwali.

The festival features a colourful mix of cultural performances, traditional and modern music and dance, delicious food, local art and craft stalls, and engaging activities for children and families. It offers a unique opportunity to experience the diverse cultures that make up our region while celebrating the universal values of light over darkness, hope, and togetherness.

WPSCC Inc. proudly hosts this event to promote unity, cultural understanding, and community spirit in the Hutt Valley and beyond.

The Japanese Film Festival is an annual event held to encourage the growth of Japanese culture and understanding in New Zealand. Each year, we try to give the people of New Zealand some insight into the culture, customs, and traditions of Japan, alongside what is popular with Japanese society today, through film.

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra - Garden Performers, Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.

Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.
Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!


Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.

description:
Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026, Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026
Get ready, Kapiti – something bold, creative, and totally unforgettable is coming your way. On Saturday, 7th March 2026, the Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival makes its explosive return at the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall, bringing together the ultimate fusion of ink, art, and live entertainment for one epic day of creativity and connection. Whether you're a tattoo enthusiast, an art lover, or someone who thrives in high-energy, artistic environments, this festival is your ticket to something truly extraordinary.

This isn’t just another tattoo expo — it’s a full-blown creative takeover. Expect to see over 40 talented artists under one roof, from the regions leading tattooists to visionary painters, sculptors, illustrators, and local craftspeople. You’ll witness live tattooing, explore interactive art installations, shop handcrafted works, and dive into workshops designed to spark your imagination. Plus, with non-stop local entertainment on the main stage — from musicians to performers and DJs — the atmosphere will be electric from start to finish.

What makes this event truly special? It’s powered by the team at Kapiti Castles — the creative minds behind the popular Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo. Known for producing vibrant, community-driven experiences, Kapiti Castles has crafted this festival as a platform for creative expression, community connection, and artistic inspiration. Whether you're an artist looking to grow your brand or a visitor eager to explore the region’s creative heartbeat, this is your moment.

The Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival is more than an event — it’s a movement. It’s a chance to meet incredible artists, get inspired, celebrate culture, and maybe even walk away with some fresh ink. With something for everyone — from art collectors to curious newcomers — this is a must-attend event for 2026.

So mark your calendars for 7th March, gather your crew, and get your tickets now. The Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026 is where creativity comes alive, and you won’t want to miss being part of it. Tickets are on sale now — don’t miss your chance to be part of Kapiti’s boldest new festival.

description:
Martinborough Music Festival 2025, Bringing the world to Martinborough for chamber music in the heart of South Wairarapa.

Join us for four exciting concerts over three days, featuring stunning New Zealand and international artists including Natalia Lomeiko (violin), Yuri Zhislin (violin/viola), Matthias Balzat and Ashley Brown (cello), Jian Liu (piano), Wilma Smith and Donald Armstrong (violin), Simon Brew (saxophone) and Caroline Henbest (viola).

These artists will bring to life extraordinary works including Zoltán Kodály's Duo for Violin and Cello, Op. 7; JS Bach's Goldberg Variations for string trio; Shostakovich's Piano Quintet in G minor, Op. 57 and Mozart's String Quintet No. 5 in D major, K.593.

The Sunday afternoon concert will also include the world premiere of Shifting Worlds, a piano quintet by renowned New Zealand composer Louise Webster, who has special ties with South Wairarapa.

Visit martinboroughmusicfestival.co.nz for more information about artists, programmes and links to ticket sales.

description:
NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash, NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash
🦇A Day of Decadence, Darkness and Delights 🕷️

Join us from midday until the shadows stretch long, as Brewtown transforms into a haunted haven of unholy delights for NZ Brewers Fest 2025 – Monster Mash!

🍻Fiendishly good Beer!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!

Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!

🍸Haunting Spirits & Wine!
New for this year! Step into our haunted cocktail bar for some seriously spooky spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some devilishly delicious drops just for you.

We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.

Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

🌮Monstrously Good Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy both the living and the undead.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

⚔️Enthralling Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling. Expect sultry burlesque, twisted characters and moments that will thrill, chill, and have you begging for more.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint – as they bring a special set just for Monster Mash! Trust us, you haven’t seen them like this before…

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

Enjoy dressing up? Go all out in your most terrifying, theatrical or jaw-dropping costume — and you might just take out the crown in our epic Best Dressed Competition, with spooky-good prizes up for grabs.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18

description:
Tartan up the Green, Gather up the clan and join us here at Brewtown Upper Hutt – Tartan Up The Green is back for 2025!

Are you ready to be blown away by the power of the Pipes and Drums as Tartan Up The Green returns this October 4th for another rousing rendition of Bagpiping, Highland Drumming and Dancing!

Our mates from RNZPBA Wellington Hawkes Bay are back to curate their all-new take on traditional pipe and drum comps with some of the finest musicians in the country.

Join us on The Greenspace for our very own family friendly, FREE to attend salute to those earth-shaking instruments of war (literally) and all things Highlands and Islands!

It won’t just be Pipers and Drummers competing for glory. Brewtown is delighted to welcome some bonnie boogying in the form of Scottish Highland Dancing, as dancers from up and down the country wow the crowd with traditional dance.

A true showcase of strength and stamina, Highland Dancing is highly technical and recognised as a sport by the Sport Council of Scotland…waltzing this aint!

So, get behind these incredible young athletes and show your support at this years Tartan Up The Green!

description:
The Runholder Presents A Boutique Festival of Wine, Gin, Food & Music, The Runholder Presents A Boutique Festival of Wine, Gin, Food & Music
Join us under a canopy of trees for an unforgettable afternoon that blends flavour, sound & celebration. Set against the stunning backdrop of Martinborough’s rolling hills and vines, this curated gathering brings together our favourite makers, movers, and shakers - ready to pour, plate, and play their hearts out.

Sip iconic artisan wines, swirl small-batch gin and savour signature gourmet bites by culinary legends.

On stage we welcome the soulful stylings and powerhouse vocals of Hollie Smith, the retro glam and infectious energy of The Beat Girls, and the genre-spinning magic of Sweet Mix Kids, interspersed with sets from DJ Takas. The only thing smoother than the wine is the soundtrack.

Our Saturday session promises an elevated, intimate atmosphere - where the wine flows, the beats drop, and the good vibes carry you through an afternoon of dancing, right into sunset.

With invited friends: Martinborough Vineyard, Te Kairanga, Escarpment, Ata Rangi, Schubert, Palliser Estate, Halite Wines, Lighthouse Gin, Mt Difficulty, Vavasour, Martinborough Brewery, Antipodes Water, The Crab Shack, Wharekauhau Estate, Shed 5, SOUL Bar & Bistro and Martin Bosley's Oyster Saloon.

Elevate your festival experience with VIP hosting at The Runholder Cottage. Indulge in premium and library wines poured by the winemakers themselves, impeccably paired with gourmet food offerings from Auckland Viaduct’s iconic SOUL Bar & Bistro. As a VIP guest, you’ll enjoy all-inclusive food and beverage with menu service for any onsite vendor, exclusive access to the dedicated VIP area with priority stage sightlines and premium hosting amenities for your comfort and convenience.

Take advantage of easy transportation options with return bus add-ons from Wellington, Masterton, Carterton, Greytown & Featherston ($30-$60), and free shuttles to and from Martinborough Square, so you can sip responsibly.

description:
Wellington Folk Festival 2025 - our 60th!, Welcome to Wellyfest!
The Wellington Folk Festival is held every Labour Weekend, celebrated on the fourth weekend of October, at Brookfield Outdoor Education Centre – a beautiful site owned by the Scouts at 562 Moores Valley Road, Wainuiomata, Lower Hutt, New Zealand.
The Festival gate is open from 3pm on the Friday, with events running over Friday evening, all day Saturday through to Sunday evening. You can come for the weekend, for a day, half day or an evening. Children (0 - 12) can attend free.
Weekend passes entitle the holders to camp onsite and there are a limited number of bunks available for sale as well.
PLEASE NOTE - ALL EARLYBIRD PRICING CLOSES AT 11.55PM ON SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER. Full-price tickets can be purchased on-line until Sunday 19th October.
After ticket sales close on Humanitix, you can purchase at the gate, from 3pm on Friday 25th of October.  Weekend tickets, day tickets and evening tickets are all available at the gate.  There may even be some bunks available still.  You can email registrations@wellingtonfolkfestival.org.nz to find out.
To read our latest news click here, click the Latest News tab in the menu above, or check out our facebook page here www.facebook.com/Wellyfest/.
If you would like to be added to our email list, sign up to our mailing list here.

For more information visit homeandgardenshow.co.nz or 'Like us' on Facebook.
We are working very hard to keep our events safe and we ask that you please stay home if you are unwell.
Show opening hours: Friday & Saturday 10-5pm, Sunday 10-4pm
FAQs
1. What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event?
Parking is available at the venue, at a cost of $10. Please note parking is card payment only (entry to the Show is card or cash).
2. What is the best time to attend?
Peak visitor times are normally between 11am - 2pm so the crowds are less outside of these times.
3. What days is the ticket valid for?
General Admission entry tickets is for one entry only and is valid for any one of the 3 event days.
Gold Card Special 1/2 price tickets valid for Friday only.
4. Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?
A printed ticket or showing the barcode on your phone to the entry staff is required.

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival, Soul, funk, jazz, fusion, rhythm and blues — it’s a celebration of sound across the city this spring. The annual Wellington Jazz Festival is back. The event packs over 100 gigs into five days in venues around the city. 
The festival features two major international acts making exclusive New Zealand debuts. Wellington will see two-time Grammy Award-winning jazz vocalist and bandleader, Gregory Porter and five-time Grammy Award-winning jazz singer, Samara Joy. Gregory Porter’s unique and timeless sound blends jazz, soul, and gospel. His influences include Bakersfield Southern Gospel and jazz legend Nat King Cole. At just 25 years old, Samara Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation. She’s redefining 21st-century jazz with a rich, mature tone and refined phrasing. 
The treats in the programme continue with Australian First Nations soul singer Bumpy, and a commissioned work by New Zealand/Congolese drummer, composer, and rhythm master  Myele Manzanza. He’ll be performing with international supergroup, lvdf. The Rodger Fox Big Band returns with a tribute to Ray Charles, and the Aotearoa Jazz Orchestra has its inaugural performance with a Duke Ellington arrangement of Tchaikovsky’s The Nutcracker Suite. Many of the hospitality venues in Courtenay Place and its surrounding streets are planning intimate jazz gigs across the festival. Follow the sound of saxophones to find a spot to park up for the night.

Wellington Spring Festival – Government House Garden tour, As part of Wellington's Spring Fetival, explore Government House gardens with the BARK garden team (90 minute tour)

Government House was opened in Newtown in 1910, and its extensive gardens have been in continuous development since then. As part of the Spring Festival, the Government House garden team is offering guided walks through our gardens. Tours will go ahead regardless of weather. Tours will not enter the main house.

Bookings are essential for the free tour. Places are limited: https://gg.govt.nz/government-house/government-house-wellington/government-house-tours/upcoming

Some parts of our grounds are not mobility friendly. Please contact the Visitor Centre direct if you have any questions regarding accessibility.

Groups wanting to organise a garden tour or house tour can email our Visitor Centre team direct: bookings@govthouse.govt.nz

If you have any questions or need more information, please email us at bookings@govthouse.govt.nz, or call us at 04-382-0837. You will receive a reminder email 24 hours before your tour.

Come to the Library to watch two documentaries about the occupation — ‘Bastion Point: Day 507’ made in 1980 and ‘Bastion Point: The Untold Story’ made almost two decades later in 1999.

Presented by the National Library of New Zealand Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa in partnership with Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision and Manatū Taonga Ministry for Culture and Heritage.

Photo: Film still from Bastion Point: Day 507 featuring Joe Hawke (right). Stills collection, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision.

description:
Dear Gentlemen, Movie Spotlight
Dear Gentlemen / Estimados señores
Country: Colombia
Genre: Drama
Audio: Spanish
Subtitles: English
Synopsis: Dear Gentlemen brings to light the little-known sufraggist movement in Colombia. Set in 1954, the film follows Esmeralda Arboleda, a fiercely intelligent leader who sparks a revolution in a society deeply rooted in patriarchal traditions – a revolution that culminates in a fierce and decisve debate. A women group embarks on a historic struggle to bring the issue of women’s right to vote before the National Constituent Assembly. With bold marches, radio appearances, and a brilliant media strategy that puts them on the front page, they achieve their goal, but the real challenge begins during the debate, where they face fierce opposition. Esmeralda Arboleda must endure personal attacks from the assembly members, and just as she is about to speak, she receives a heartbreaking call: her son has suffered a serious accident. She is torn between her duty as a mother and her commitment to the cause, with an unfavorable outcome. Although all seems to be lost, her perseverance leads to a historic victory when women’s suffrage is finally approved, marking a turning point in Colombia’s history.
Rated: PG - Parental Guidance Recommended for younger viewers
Free Entry | RSVP required |

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Film screening: GAGA
Join us for a special screening of the 2022 Taiwanese comedy-drama film GAGA, featuring a Q&A with the award-winning Director, Laha Mebow

About this Event

Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.

Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.


Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

description:
Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career, Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career
In this month’s Friends of the Turnbull event, author and lecturer Annabel Cooper will talk about researching New Zealand filmmaker Rudall Hayward, best known for his silent films but also his later feature films ‘Rewi’s Last Stand’ and ‘To Love a Māori’.

Join us at the Library or online. Register if you’d like to join this talk and we'll send you the link to use on the day:

Rediscovering Rudall Hayward
Join us for a fascinating talk by historian and author Annabel Cooper as she delves into the life and legacy of Rudall Hayward — a trailblazer of New Zealand filmmaking.

Although not widely known today, Rudall’s career spanned from the early 1900s to the 1970s. He made four feature-length films during New Zealand’s silent film era, later navigating the financial challenges of accessing new sound equipment to make documentaries, educational films, and two more feature films — Rewi’s Last Stand (1940) and the first New Zealand film to be shot in colour, To Love a Māori (1972).

Drawing on research for her biography of Rudall Hayward and his family, Annabel Cooper will explore his enduring contributions to cinema, his collaborative work with his wives Hilda and Ramai, and the cultural legacy he left behind.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Associate Professor Annabel Cooper taught at the University of Otago for 30 years, and published on a number of New Zealand topics including gender history and film. Her last book, Filming the Colonial Past: The New Zealand Wars on Screen, is the subject of an exhibition, He Riri Awatea: Filming the New Zealand Wars, curated with Ariana Tikao for the New Zealand Portrait Gallery and now showing at Canterbury Museum.

Jenin Jenin Screening, This spring from the 28th of August to the 2nd of October we will be screening a series of excellent Palestinian films, old and new, every week at two/fiftyseven on Willis Street, with ticket sales going to the Gazan mutual aid group The Sameer Project.
The Sameer Project is an on-the-ground aid organisation organised by Palestinians in the diaspora, which crowdfunds in order to provide tents, medical care and direct cash aid to those most affected in Gaza. They can be found on Instagram at @thesameerproject.
More information:
Jenin Jenin includes testimony from Jenin residents after the Israeli army’s Defensive Shield operation, during which the city and camp were the scenes of fierce fighting. The operation ended with Jenin flattened and scores of Palestinians killed. Palestinians as well as numerous human rights groups accused Israel of committing war crimes in the April 2002 attack on the refugee camp. The sad question forces itself on the spectator: What will become of a country, a people when its children are confronted with war and violence from a very early age?

description:
Martial Law Film Screening, In remembrance of the victims of human rights violations and extrajudicial killings during the Martial Law in the Philippines, please join us for a free/koha screening of the "Batas Militar" documentary in Te Whanganui-a-Tara.
NOTE: For a list of trigger warnings, please see this document. Since we will be viewing and discussing potentially sensitive topics, the event will have an Open Door Policy, which means that you may leave the venue any time, for any reason, and will not be judged for doing so.
WHAT IS MARTIAL LAW?
"Martial law refers to the replacement of civil rule by military rule. This may be characterized by curfews, the dispensation of military tribunal rulings on civilians, and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus. The writ of habeas corpus, which in Latin refers to “having the body”, is a citizen’s protection against unlawful imprisonment. This is suspended in times of crisis to expedite justice" (Martial Law Museum).
WHY IS IT IMPORTANT TO TALK ABOUT TODAY?
Human rights violations and extrajudicial killings are still on-going in the Philippines under President Bongbong Marcos, the son of the dictator Ferdinand Marcos Sr. who proclaimed Martial Law in 1972, and Vice President Sara Duterte, the daughter of former President Rodrigo Duterte who spearheaded the violent War on Drugs in 2016 (Karapatan).
WHY WOULD I WANT TO JOIN THE FILM SCREENING?
The film screening is for anyone who is keen to learn about the Martial Law Era, wants to share their experience during the Martial Law (or something similar) through group discussion, wants to meet new people, wants to watch a Philippine film/documentary, or just wants to have snacks.
I WANT TO JOIN BUT I'M FROM TĀMAKI MAKAURAU / CHRISTCHURCH / THE PHILIPPINES.
We will stream the film through Zoom for viewers outside Te Whanganui-a-Tara, however, there may be internet and other technical difficulties during the event itself. Also please make sure to select the "Online" ticket option when RSVPing.
HOW MUCH IS THE TICKET?
The film screening is free but we appreciate koha for the venue/snacks/donations to Philippine non-governmental organisations (NGOs).
NOTE: This is an LGBTQ+ friendly event.

description:
Mother Tongue: A Sri Lankan food story • WLG screening, Motivated by things that are very tasty, Bhagya and Carl travel to the motherland of Sri Lanka to document forest gardens, coconut mills, rice paddies and Aachi’s house. After a couple years bringing Lankan flavours to the people of Ōtepoti - and armed with the cultural knowledge of diaspora kids - they want to know: Who grew this and why is it so delicious?
Follow us on IG: @media_syndicate
A true labour of love, this film was created to honour the people who put so much work into the food we eat. To this end, proceeds will be donated to our friends at The Movement for Land and Agricultural Reform (MONLAR) so that they can continue in their work for a cooperative, ecological and just food system.
MONLAR's mission is to "cooperate towards building a peoples movement by capacity building and mobilizing of small farmers and marginalized communities, who have become victims of the globalization structures, to protect natural resources and human rights and to lobby for change and implement alternative policies that are favorable and sustainable."
Running time: 42 minutes + QnA with filmmaker Bhagya Herath

description:
Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon, Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon
Surprise we are running a 35mm Mystery Marathon very soon! We have had some exciting news that we cannot share for now but as a result we must move our beautiful 35mm from its usual location into storage for a bit. We are not sure when it will be set back up so to celebrate we are running a marathon of six 35mm features across one Saturday!

We will kick off the first film at 1:30pm sharp on Saturday and will have a short dinner break after the third film. All going to plan we should be done by around 12:30am.

In terms of the features, we have films from the 1960s through to the early 2000s with a mix of comedies, sci-fi, horror and cult classics! Granted not all of these films would be considered masterpieces but there is nothing more fun than sitting in a crowd not knowing what could be coming next!

We will have a snack menu you can pre-order before the first film so aim to arrive around 1:00pm to order. The breaks between films will be very short (probably just enough time for the projectionist to thread up the next film) so make sure you come prepared for back-to-back screenings.

This event has strictly no digital projection, it’s all film all the time. Now in theory it should all playback without a hitch as we are bringing in some of the best projectionist’s Wellington has. But 35mm is a strange beast that can sometimes throw up the odd issue.

All tickets are $50

Seating is general admission and cinema entrance will be determined by earliest ticket purchase times.
