description:
Feed Your Senses, Step into an immersive experience where nature’s core elements — stone, clay, wood, water, fire, and air — are brought to life through a dynamic fusion of artistic mediums. Explore interactive installations and captivating performances that engage all of your senses with visual art, sculpture, sound, and more. Throughout the evening, enjoy six unique canapés and six meticulously crafted drinks, each inspired by the work of a different artist. Each exhibit reflects the raw power and beauty of the natural world, as local artists push boundaries to bring these elements to life in real-time.

As you journey through Foxglove’s Secret Wardrobe, you'll be surrounded by live artistry unfolding around you, creating an environment filled with raw creativity and vibrant energy. Aphrodisiac-inspired canapés and expertly paired beverages complement the visual experience, bringing each artist’s medium to life while celebrating Wellington’s rich and diverse creative community.

This culinary and sensory pairing will transport you deeper into the world of artistry, blending food and creativity in unexpected and delightful ways.

This event goes beyond simple exhibition — it’s a celebration of Wellington's local talent where the boundaries between food, art, and sensory experience are beautifully blurred. Whether you’re an art aficionado or a culinary enthusiast, this immersive experience promises to engage your senses in an unforgettable way.

description:
Honeymoon Around Asia, Honeymoon Around Asia: A Love Letter to Flavour
Pack your bags—Chow’s taking you on a romantic getaway through the flavours of Asia (no passport required
)
This five-course love affair is a journey through Thailand’s fiery passion, Japan’s delicate romance, Vietnam’s garden-fresh charm, Singapore’s bold intensity, and Korea’s comforting soul. Each dish is a love letter to its homeland—served with a playful twist and paired with mini Asia-inspired cocktails designed to make your tastebuds swoon
Expect an immersive vibe with house & disco beats, passport-style menus, and cheeky photo ops like our “Just Married to Dumplings
” station and “Love Letters Wall.” Whether you’re bringing your soulmate, your bestie, or your fellow foodie—it’s a night to indulge, laugh, and fall head-over-heels… for the food
One night only. Five courses. Five destinations. One unforgettable culinary getaway.
General release tickets are on sale from 12pm Friday 27 June
Spots are limited — Book Now !!

description:
I-Sarn Thai KanTok, Join Daeng from Tuk Tuk Thai for a deeply personal culinary journey to the heart of E-Sarn, the north-eastern region of Thailand she once called home. This one-night-only event celebrates the traditional Kan-Tok style of dining – a communal meal served on handwoven bamboo trays and shared amongst family and friends. This event is made to be shared, the ticket price is for a shared menu for two. 

Growing up in the small town of Tha Bo near the Mekong Delta, Daeng’s childhood was filled with stories of rice farming, village generosity, and dishes cooked from what the garden offered. In E-Sarn, meals were acts of love, shared daily around the Kan-Tok with laughter, music, and warmth.

Now, Daeng invites you to gather at her table and experience the flavours of her upbringing. You’ll be served nine traditional dishes on a beautifully crafted bamboo tray, designed for sharing, just as they are in her village.

On the Kan-Tok:
Hor Mok Salmon – Steamed salmon in banana leaves, marinated with herbs, spices, and coconut milk
Mok Nor Mai with Pork Belly – Pork belly steamed with bamboo shoots
Larb Gai – A celebratory chicken mince salad with fresh herbs and toasted rice
E-Sarn Sausages – House-made, spiced and fermented in true north-eastern style
Nam Prik Tomato – Roasted tomato dipping sauce with chillies, garlic, and shallots
Som Tum – Green papaya salad with a sweet, sour, spicy kick
Sticky Rice – Soaked overnight and steamed in traditional bamboo baskets
Fresh and Steamed Seasonal Vegetables – To enjoy with sauces and mains

Dessert:
Kanom Chan – Thai layered jelly cake
Kanom Mun – Tapioca and coconut pudding

Pull up a seat at Daeng’s table and discover the stories, flavours, and traditions that shaped her childhood.
Single tickets or odd numbers unable to be catered to.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Interislander: Pop-up Burger, Interislander has been a long-time supporter of Visa Wellington on a Plate, the famous hospitality event that lights up the Wellington region each August.

The Love Ferry
Featuring a Poneke Red brioche bun, with a beef & pork patty seasoned with a mix of smoked paprika, garlic, and a touch of cayenne pepper. Melted Kapiti brie cheese with caramelised onions, roasted red peppers, rocket and truffle aioli. Topped with crispy Harrington’s bacon and pickled jalepenos for those who like a little heat. Served with a side of crispy fries sprinkled with smoked paprika and sea salt at $20. For the perfect pairing, we offer a Garage Project Beer match for $12.

Pop-up Burger at Wellington Railway Station
We've set up a pop-up burger truck outside the Wellington Railway Station. This will allow the public to indulge in our burger and fries without needing to sail on the Interislander. Its also available to passengers when travelling the Cook Strait on the Ferry.

description:
JETAA Wellington - Brewkaiwa September @ Mean Doses, We will be having our September Brewkaiwa at Mean Doses, a bold and modern craft brewery in the heart of Wellington. Known for its inventive beers and laid-back atmosphere, it’s the perfect place to share a drink and good conversation.
Brewkaiwa is JETAA’s monthly casual meetup for anyone with any connection to Japan.
We’re a diverse group of people who have studied, worked, or lived in Japan or have been invited along by someone who has.
Come join us for a brew and stay for the kaiwa! Bring your friends!
***Japanese or alcohol consumption NOT REQUIRED!***
Brewkaiwaとは
一杯いかがですか？
JETAAがウェリントンで親睦会を開催するとどうなるのか？その結果、BREWKAIWA！
2020年に始まった、ブリューカイワは、ウェリントンの様々なバーで毎月開催されている飲み会です。大人気の国際交流グルップです！！！ 日本で働いたり、住んだり、旅行したことのある人達に人気のあるイベントです！！！お酒を飲んで、友達を出来、素敵なごちそうを食べ、おまけに異文化を知られます！
日本語が話せる外国人も良く参加しているので、日本語しか話せなくても全然大丈夫です！
是非来てください！

Whether you're a food lover or curious about Chinese culture, this event is perfect for you. Don’t miss this tasty experience!

description:
Le Petit Chef, InterContinental Wellington proudly presents the first official Le Petit Chef experience in New Zealand - an extraordinary fusion of theatre, storytelling, and fine dining.

Step into the whimsical animated world of Le Petit Chef, the world’s tiniest and most determined chef, as he embarks on a globe-trotting quest to source the finest ingredients. Using groundbreaking 3D projection mapping technology, your table transforms into a magical stage, where continents shift, spices fly, and the art of cooking comes thrillingly to life before your eyes.

As the journey unfolds, a five-course menu is served in perfect harmony with the story. Highlights include Wairarapa crayfish bouillabaisse, corn-fed chicken with Perigord truffle, and a decadent Valrhona chocolate dessert. Choose from the Grand Menu ($180), Classic Menu ($140), Vegetarian Menu ($140), or a dedicated Kids Menu $70). While each menu offers a distinct culinary experience, the stunning visual show remains the same for all guests and is centered around the Grand Menu storyline.

Please note, while primarily designed for individual bookings, some shared seating may apply due to the technical nature of the performance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Love Language, Calling budding poets and hopeless romantics - this is your opportunity to share your love of language, with a food and poetry degustation. 
This four-course dinner is a physical manifestation of love and an ode to food. Join Simon Sweetman, Wellington writer, critic, musician and poet, as he reads some of his own poetry, and yours too if you're feeling game. Chefs Tim and Aaron Banks will lovingly create a four-course dinner with ingredients locally sourced and lovingly produced by small scale sustainable farmers... and perhaps they will read their own poems too. 
If you're feeling poetic bring along your own poem specially crafted around this year's festival theme 'Food is Love'. It can be as long or short as you like, as happy or sad, comical or tragic, Keats or Bukowski. Spot prizes for various categories including 'Most Related to the Theme' and 'Most Obviously Foodie' poems. Includes four courses, and a welcome glass of bubbles on arrival.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Love in Scent, Join fragrance aficionado Benny Castles for an immersive journey into the WORLD of love, told through the art of scent. In this exclusive olfactive experience, indulge in small bites and sip on a glass (or three!) of something delightful, setting the perfect mood for exploring the emotional power of fragrance.

Over the course of the evening, you’ll sample up to twelve unique fragrances, each one tied to a captivating love story that inspired its creation. Learn the intimate tales behind these scents and discover how they evoke the passions and emotions that shape our experiences of love. Whether you're a fragrance enthusiast or a newcomer, this sensory journey is sure to arouse your olfactory senses and deepen your appreciation for the art of perfume.
label: Food & Drink

description: Love is Blind, Experience an unforgettable blind gin tasting led by Southward's owner & distiller Frankie Mcphail. With sight removed, you will be relying on your other senses as you are guided through tasting six gins with curated sound by DJ Juniper enhancing the experience. Snacks will be served between each tasting while you remove your blindfold, take notes and make your guesses.

description: Love the Wine You're With, Join the team from Matahiwi Estate for a fun and fearless wine tasting. Strip away the pretense of wine while tasting six glasses from new flavours, to old favourites and unique styles all while enjoying a shared charcuterie pairing. No question is too big or small, this is your chance to sip, learn, and explore in a relaxed, welcoming atmosphere. Come curious, leave confident or maybe just a little less confused by wine speak - but most of all, enjoy!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Lunch Speaker Series, Noble Rot invites you to enjoy a relaxed lunch in style. While away your afternoon with a leisurely three-course menu as they keep the wine flowing amongst you and your friends. They've lined up two incredible guest speakers at the forefront of the wine industry to entertain you with their stories, knowledge and insights into current trends in a relaxed but intimate atmosphere. You'll wish all learning was done this way. It’s the perfect excuse to treat your friends, your mum or your date.
 
Guest Speakers & Dates:

Saturday 9th — ‘Small Region, Big Sky’
Katherine Jacobs and her husband Jeremy embarked on a dream to produce some of Martinborough’s finest wines from their special vineyard in Te Muna, and they’ve achieved great success! Katherine will speak about upcoming trends, big dreams and hidden secrets in our favourite region’s wine scene.
 
Saturday 23rd — ‘A Rosie Afternoon’ 
Enjoy the company of Rosie Finn of Neudorf Vineyards, second generation of one of New Zealand's most prestigious wineries in Nelson. You’ll have the opportunity to ask Rosie all about current trends as she combines the story of her family winery’s historic roots and its impact on the landscape of New Zealand fine wines.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Maille Sunday Kai, Escape the winter chill and head along to Cuba St Tavern for some Sunday Kai with Maille Mustard, running every Sunday of August. Each week features a different delectable roast, served with either a Maille Dijon Bloody Mary or warming mulled wine, and finished with a house-made dessert. Sunday has never tasted so good! Bookings available from 1pm.

$50 for 2 courses
$65 for 2 courses inc a Maille Bloody Mary or House made Mulled wine

Menu
Every Maille Sunday Kai event will offer a vegetarian option of eggplant parmigiana with buffalo mozzarella, Maille Dijon mustard, tomato ragù, garlic potato and broccolini.

3 August
Free-range roast porchetta served with garlic potato, creamed spinach, broccolini, Yorkshire pudding, Maille wholegrain mustard jus and apple sauce.
Dessert: Sticky toffee pudding with custard.

10 August
Roast duck breast served with duck fat roast potatoes, Chinese broccoli, mushrooms, Yorkshire pudding, and Maille Dijon mustard and onion cream.
Dessert: Dark chocolate torte with orange mascarpone.

17 August
Conscious Valley roast lamb shoulder with garlic roast potatoes, honey-glazed carrots, minted peas, Yorkshire pudding, Maille wholegrain mustard jus and mint sauce.
Dessert: Bread and butter pudding with ginger gelato and crème anglaise.

24 August
Half a roast chicken with duck fat roast potatoes, garlic green beans, cavolo nero, Yorkshire pudding, chicken schmaltz and Maille mustard gravy.
Dessert: Steamed honey pudding with custard and honey gelato.

31 August
First Light roast sirloin served with honey-glazed carrots, duck fat roast potatoes, cabbage and bacon, Yorkshire pudding, horseradish, Maille Dijon mustard and jus.
Dessert: Chocolate fondant with vanilla bean gelato.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Makers and Shakers, Makers and Shakers is back for 2025. Indulge in three one-of-a-kind love potions, each masterfully crafted by the talented team at Cuckoo Emporium and served in a unique ceramic vessel. These beautiful, handmade pieces come from the skilled local potters of the Wellington Potters Association. As you sip and savour your delicious concoctions, listen to the shakers tell their love stories behind their potions and the makers speak the sonnets of their creations. Your ticket includes three alcoholic cocktails, light snacks and three bespoke ceramic pieces to take home.
 
 (*Pottery shown are the vessels from the 2024 event and will be different this year)
label: Food & Drink

description:
Michelin Star to Martinborough, Join celebrated Chef and Union Square owner Adam Newell for a once-in-a-lifetime culinary experience. Take a journey through four decades of his exceptional career, including his Michelin-starred tenure at the renowned Fulham Road Restaurant in London. This exclusive event will offer an intimate exploration of Chef Newell's evolution as a chef and restaurateur, showcasing iconic dishes from four pivotal periods in his career.

Set in the elegant Napoleon dining room inside the historic Martinborough Hotel, each course represents a defining moment in Chef Newell’s career. Paired with fine wines selected by in-house Sommelier Carl Fraser, this evening is designed to be a feast for both the palate and the mind.

Course 1: 1980s – Claridge’s Hotel, London
A taste of the refined sophistication from one of London’s most prestigious hotels.
Course 2: 1990s – Le Gavroche, London
A nod to the classic French techniques that helped shape Chef Newell's early career.
Course 3: 2000s – Zibibbo, Wellington
A celebration of New Zealand’s finest ingredients and a significant step in his culinary journey.
Course 4: 2010s – Union Square Bistro, Martinborough
Reflecting his achievements at Union Square, the course that represents his current culinary vision.

This evening offers guests a unique chance to experience the evolution of one chef's journey through extraordinary dishes paired with wines that elevate each moment.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Netherfield Ball, Step into the enchanting world of Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice at Homewood, where the timeless elegance of a Regency-era ball comes to life. This evening of romance, music, and culinary delight invites you to relive the iconic moments of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy’s fateful meeting.

Guests will be greeted with crafted cocktails inspired by love potions, showcasing ingredients from some of the finest distilleries in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. As the evening unfolds, indulge in a carefully curated selection of canapés, created with fresh ingredients sourced from Homewood’s own garden, evoking the flavours and charm of the Regency period.

The grand setting of Homewood, the esteemed residence of the British High Commissioner, will transport you to a bygone era. With the glow of garden lighting, live music filling the air, and an atmosphere brimming with romance, you’ll feel as if you’ve stepped into Austen’s world. Dancing will play a central role in the evening, allowing guests to immerse themselves in the grace and grandeur of the Regency social scene.

Whether you’re an Austen devotee, a fan of Bridgerton, or simply drawn to the allure of historical elegance, this event promises to captivate your imagination and senses. Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a night filled with charm, sophistication, and timeless romance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Next Gen Cook Off, The Next Gen Cook Off returns for its fifth year, and things are heating up at Everybody Eats.
Every Monday in August, four of Wellington’s freshest young chefs will go head-to-head in a high-energy kitchen takeover, serving up epic three-course dinners using rescued food.

Each chef will be given the same protein, generously provided by Meat Direct, but everything else is a surprise—ingredients are revealed that morning, based on what’s come in. Menus are created on the spot, and dishes are served to a buzzing, hungry crowd. It’s fast-paced, creative chaos with serious culinary skills on display. Guests get a front-row seat to the action, while supporting a truly game-changing enterprise.

4 August — Jessie Gibberd, Loretta
Originally from rural Waikato, Jessie Gibberd made the move to Wellington to study, but it was the buzz of hospitality that captured her heart. Swapping textbooks for tongs, she left her degree behind to dive headfirst into the kitchen. Now a chef de partie at Loretta, Jessie brings a grounded, fresh perspective to one of the city’s most beloved eateries.

11 August — Felipe Molina, El Matador
Hailing from Chile, Felipe Molina is a professional chef with over 15 years of experience in kitchens around the world. Having worked in several countries and world-class restaurants, Felipe brings a global sensibility to his craft. With a passion for seafood, meats, and bold, expressive flavours, his cooking is shaped by travel and tradition, blending international influence with creativity on every plate.

18 August — Zane Gupwell, Graze
Zane Gupwell began his hospitality journey at just 15, washing dishes at a local café in Mount Eden. From there, he headed to Queenstown, learning from a wide range of chefs and kitchen styles before challenging himself with a move to Wellington. Since then, he’s worked at some of the city’s top restaurants and now brings his thoughtful, evolving style to Graze Wine Bar.

25 August — Lulu Temmuyin, Mr Go’s
Lulu Temmuyin is a chef who loves pushing boundaries, even when they’re unexpected. Lactose intolerant but obsessed with cheese, and not a fan of lamb but winner of a lamb cooking competition, Lulu is all about surprises. At Mr Go’s, she brings bold, sustainable flavour to the forefront, blending personality with punch in every dish.

Everybody Eats runs on a pay-what-you-can model, transforming food waste into gourmet meals and bringing the community together over good kai. The Next Gen Cook Off celebrates and champions this mission, proving that rescued food can be next-level delicious.

The Next Gen Cook Off is proudly supported by The Gas Hub.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Nyumbani: A Taste of Tanzania, Journey through the heart of Tanzania with dishes that feel like home - comforting, bold, and full of love. This special five-course degustation is created by Chef Shuchi Bhardwaj, a baker who grew up in Tanzania and carries its flavours, traditions, and warmth in her heart. 
Whether it’s the warm embrace of coconut-infused stews, smoky grilled meats, or fragrant spiced rice, each course is a reminder of how food connects us. This menu brings authentic East African flavours to the table, reimagined in a modern way that feels like home. Each course is matched with a carefully selected wine to enhance the flavours of the dish. Expect generous hospitality and a setting that feels like stepping into a Tanzanian family gathering.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Santa Cipolla, “Holy Onion”. For the entire month, Cicio Cacio Osteria is getting brave and bold, celebrating the magic of vegetables in all their glory, especially the santa cipolla (aka the holy onion). 
Vegetables bring colour, life and joy. In Italy, they mark the rhythm of the seasons, stir up cherished memories and signal the excitement of fresh beginnings. Come along and experience vibrant flavours with playful snacks, fun street food, freshly baked breads, handmade pasta and a brand new range of dishes that celebrate the beauty, bounty and simplicity of Italian cuisine.
label: Food & Drink

description: Santiago to Buenos Aires, Noble Rot sommeliers Maciej Zimny and Jessica Wood invite you to embark on their recent road trip through Chile and Argentina. They will indulge you with stories and share their experiences through these two fantastic wine countries alongside a South American themed five-course degustation menu including dishes they enjoyed on their journey. Relax and enjoy their tales and insight into why the wines taste the way they do, the key stylistic differences between the two countries, and learn from them first-hand the secrets of why Chilean and Argentine wines are ones to watch in the future.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Saturday 'BAKES' By Onslow College, Each Saturday, we offer a variety of sourdough products next to Onslow College. We always have doughnuts, but on Saturdays we offer bread, savoury baked items (this Saturday, we have brioche), and mini-celebratory sourdough doughnuts.
All products can be pre-ordered and picked up on Saturday morning through our website.
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/weekly-menu/
EFTPOS is always available.
Our boxed mini-celebratory doughnuts, 70% of the original size, are available for a sale price of $25 for a box of all six flavours.
Our regular doughnuts cost $6 each or $22 for a box of 4 doughnuts.
We also offer catering at Family Kitchen with Mark, so if you have a function or need for in-house dining, check out all our packages on our website. Our doughnuts are also available for purchase all week. Contact Mark on 021 0223 0824 for next-day pickup.
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/grazing-tables-theme.../
All our doughnuts contain a lively sourdough & biga starter, for a fuller flavour profile and a springy texture.
Have you tried our sourdough doughnuts yet?
Our doughnuts can be pre-ordered and picked up on the day to avoid disappointment (should we run out).
We launch a new flavour every two weeks and have created over 180 combinations since selling three years ago.
Support has been phenomenal, and we thank everyone so very much indeed for the weekly sales.
If you are not following us on our social media channels, please consider doing so, as it helps the company grow and increases the exposure of our products. Thank you.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Sconnoisseur, Get ready to master the art of making Wellington's iconic cheese scones at Pravda Café. Widely regarded as the home of the city's best cheese scones, Pravda's creations are so beloved, they often sell out before you can blink. Now, you can learn the secrets behind their mouthwatering scones firsthand.

In this hands-on workshop, you’ll be guided through mixing and preparing your own batch of Pravda’s famous cheese scones. Once your dough is ready, you'll hand them off to be baked to crispy flaky perfection. While they cook, relax with a cup of tea or coffee, and once your scones are ready, you’ll enjoy the fruits of your labour fresh from the oven.

The best part? You’ll get to take home the coveted recipe, allowing you to recreate these legendary scones in your own kitchen whenever you want. This is a perfect opportunity to learn a piece of Wellington’s culinary history and enjoy a deliciously rewarding experience.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Sip the Sky: Paint, Sip and Stargaze, Paint:
Begin the evening with a night sky-inspired painting session at Ventana Art Space - 7 Kitchener Street. Whether you're a seasoned artist or picking up a brush for the first time, this relaxed, hands-on experience invites you to create under the spell of twilight tones and celestial charm.

Sip:
Then head next door for a guided wine tasting from the passionate team at The Good Way (located beside the Martinborough Brewery on Ohio Street), showcasing a selection of their elegant, small-batch wines. Find your favourite and grab a bottle to take home—perfect for gifting or continuing the magic later.

Taste:
Indulge your senses with a chocolate tasting hosted by Elly from be happy chocolate. Sample her handcrafted, ethically made bars and select your favourite block to take home. Please advise any dietary requirements when booking. Warm your hands around a velvety be happy hot chocolate and...

Stargaze:
Head outside for a gentle stroll to Considine Park with Charlotte from Wairarapa Dark Sky. Walk in the Dark while sipping hot chocolate. A chance to understand the benefits of the dark sky and finish with some star gazing.

Timing is flexible to allow for moving between locations, if you'd like to order food from The Social Kitchen food truck at the Brewery, etc. The latest finish time would be 8.45pm.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Snacks Amore, When the host brings you bread, instead of a red flag...Snacks Amore!
Amuse Snack Bar invites food lovers to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of light-hearted speed dating and snack-based bonding at their Euro-inspired aperitivo haven. Whether you are after a snack (human) or a snack (sustenance), you're guaranteed to leave with a full heart and a satisfied appetite.
Each attendee will enjoy 12 mini dates and 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, pasta alla norma, porchetta, and zabaione, all served in perfect bite-sized form. A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home. Throughout the event, wines curated by the charming Richard Klein of Artigiano Imports will be on offer, alongside Amuse’s house spritz, Negroni, and Parrotdog Lager.
The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming – more aperitivo hour than high-pressure matchmaking. The Amuse team, also musicians, will guide the evening with playful icebreakers, musical moments, and a light-touch structure that makes meeting new people easy and enjoyable.
Two themed evenings allow guests to choose their best fit:

Evening 1: General Assembly
Grouped on the night by chosen generation:
• 5:30pm – Millennials (28–45)
• 7:30pm – Gen X (40–60)

Evening 2: Rainbow Night
Grouped by dating preference.
• 6:30pm – she for her upstairs, he for him downstairs.

The event warmly welcomes all gender identities and sexual orientations. Attendees will be asked to indicate who they’re interested in dating at checkout, but gender identity remains private unless individuals wish to share it. Symbols and nametags on the night will help create a fun and inclusive vibe. Amuse Snack Bar is proud to be an LGBTQIA+ friendly space.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Snacks Amore: Rainbow night - WOAP snack based speed bonding, IRL! Zero dating apps required, We warmly invite you to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of snack-based bonding. Speed friending is heartedly encouraged along side the serious speed daters so there is no need to miss out on the fun!
Amuse Snack Bar is the new Euro-inspired aperitivo haven on Willis Street. We are making our WOAP debut and singling out the foodie LGBTQIA+ singles and mingles. WE pride ourselves on providing the warmest of hospitality at Amuse Snack bar.
Our gorgeous hosts will provide musical entertainment and a match of perfect Italian wines and aperitivo bevvies. Your heart and bellies will be equally full tonight!
You'll enjoy mini speed dates with our crowd of foodies! Plus 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, parmigiana, porchetta, and cantucci, all served in perfect bite-sized form.
A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home and curl up with on the couch.
Our event kicks off at 6.30pm with a drink and a mingle before we split into two areas of the restaurant for the serious dating
• upstairs - she for her
label: Food & Drink

description:
Spy in the Wild, Step into a world of mystery, flavour, and espionage at The Green Man Pub on Wednesday, 23rd October.
Doors open at 6:00pm, with the main event kicking off at 6:30pm. You’ll be welcomed with a sealed mission envelope containing your assignment for the evening. In teams, you’ll work to crack codes, decipher tasting notes, and unravel clues inspired by Spy Valley’s wines and the stories behind them.
Along the way, enjoy five chef-crafted canapés, each perfectly matched with a hand-picked Spy Valley wine. Expect a captivating atmosphere enhanced by lasers and special effects, transforming the pub into a true espionage experience.
🎟️ Tickets from $50 – includes six canapés with wine pairings and your mission dossier. Places are limited, so secure your spot before this top-secret evening sells out.
label: Food & Drink

label: Food & Drink

description: Sweet Sensations, Noble Rot wants to sing the praises of sweet wines and help you to learn that they aren't just one note. They'll showcase a range of wines from around the world that lean towards the sweeter side without leaving a cloying sensation on your palate, enhanced by a specially-curated five-course degustation menu from entree to dessert. If you would like to explore your favourite level of sweetness in wine, this event is for you. The knowledgeable Noble Rot team are here to show you that sweetness is one of wine’s most versatile assets, as well-balanced sweetness in wine can be delicate, elegant and complementary to both sweet and savoury dishes. Discover how some grape varieties are more suited to producing sweeter wines and how their level of sweetness is achieved. If you're into the sweeter things in life, this one is for you.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Taste of Croatia: Fritule on Sun 24 Aug, Come along this Sunday 24 August at 2-4pm to enjoy fritule, a traditional Dalmatian festive dessert, often cooked at Christmas.
Fritule are one of the most requested recipes we’ve had for Taste of Croatia, so come down this Sunday when Danica Rudelj will be sharing her recipe!
Danica will be making her dough beforehand, which will mean we will have more time to enjoy eating it.
The event picture is of Jamie Oliver’s version.
Let Dave Guerin know if you’re coming to the 24 August session at dave@ed.co.nz or 021 404 334.
label: Food & Drink

description:
The Enchanted Ale Quarter, Enter the magical realm of The Enchanted Ale Quarter, a fairytale-inspired pop-up tavern where whimsy, wonder and craft beer collide.

Step into a storybook setting, with twinkling lights, woodland decor, and forest-fantasy touches around every corner. Feast on gnome and fairy-themed comfort food like the solstice salad, loaded forest fries, sirens & ships fish & chips, and a decadent dark forest brownie, all paired with enchanted brews and mythical tipples.

Cosy, curious, and otherworldly, The Enchanted Ale Quarter brings a little magic to Wellington’s winter nights. Dust off your wings and join us for a pint, some sustenance or a potion, no quest required.
label: Food & Drink

description:
The Love Ferry, Interislander is docking onshore to bring burger lovers something truly special — The Love Ferry a spicy beef and pork patty with melted Kāpiti brie, caramelised onions, roasted red peppers, rocket, truffle aioli, crispy Harringtons bacon and pickled jalapeños in a Poneke Bakery red brioche bun, with smoked paprika and sea salt sprinkled fries.
This gourmet tribute to the love of food is served straight from the iconic Interislander ship box. Back by popular demand, the Interislander pop-up burger truck is making waves once again, offering a taste of the Interislander experience without even setting sail.
label: Food & Drink

description:
The Wellington Food Show, Are you ready to reignite your passion for cooking and get inspired with new flavours? Then look no further than The Food Show, Wellington's ultimate foodie extravaganza! This isn’t just another trip to the market — it’s an immersive culinary adventure that will excite all your senses.

Prepare to witness culinary rockstars in action as they whip up their signature dishes live! Renowned chefs and culinary stars, including MasterChef winners Nadia Lim, Sam Low, and the hilarious Annabelle White, will be sharing their tips, tricks, and insider knowledge in the Chance Voight Cooking Theatre. Whether you’re looking to master a new dish or get ideas to elevate your meals, this is your chance to get inspired and bring restaurant-worthy meals into your own kitchen.

Beyond the live cooking demonstrations, The Food Show is packed with exclusive show specials you won’t want to miss. Stock up on pantry essentials at unbeatable prices, discover hidden gems from local producers, or indulge in luxurious gourmet treats — all while saving big on products you can’t find anywhere else.

Whether you're a seasoned chef or just getting started, The Food Show is your ticket to discovering the best in food, flavour, and fun.
label: Food & Drink

description: Tire-toi une bûche, Executive Chef Jonny Taggart shares his love for the classic – and not-so-classic – flavours of Quebec. Fresh from a culinary adventure in Montreal, Jonny returns with an open heart, an inspired palate, and plenty to share. This special menu will feature everything from Tourtière (French Canadian meat pie) and smoked meat sandwiches to the beloved pairing of poutine with a steamie (Montreal-style hot dog), along with the sweet and comforting tarte farlouche. No need to book. Just come along with your friends and family and enjoy these French Canadian delights!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Urban Wine Walk | Pōneke Wellington (NZ), ON SALE TIMES
Presale Access - Thursday 11 September, 12pm NZT - Register Here
General Access - Thursday 11 September, 2pm NZT
----
The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.
HOW IT WORKS
Kick things off at your chosen starting spot with something to eat, and then let the adventure unfold. Wander at your own pace, glass in hand, discovering incredible wines and venues along the way.
With a stellar line-up of winemakers, good vibes at every stop, and a guaranteed sell-out crowd, the Urban Wine Walk is the ultimate self-guided tasting experience you and your crew won’t want to miss!
PARTICIPATING VENUES & WINEMAKERS
1 - Choice Bros Ft. Coney Wines (NZ)
2 - Glou Glou Ft. Halite (NZ)
3 - Little Beer Quarter Ft. Hopes Grove & Aard (NZ)
4 - Lulu Bar Ft. Margrain Vineyard (NZ)
5 - Noble Rot Ft. VALLI (NZ)
6 - Panhead Tory St Ft. The Good Way (NZ)
7 - The Arborist Rooftop Bar Ft. Matawhero (NZ)
8 - The Tasting Room Ft. Tettonica Wines (NZ)
*Please note that traditional venue menus may vary due to the nature of the event.
TICKETS
Vino Lover Pass – $79 + Booking Fee (Limited Availability)
WHAT’S INCLUDED
Wine Tastings – Up to 3 wines per winemaker along the trail
$10 Food Voucher – Redeem at your nominated starting venue (before 1pm)
$25 Wine Voucher – Put towards event-day wine orders (six-pack minimum, participating producers only)
Event Essentials – Your official wristband & keepsake tasting glass
EVENT REGISTRATION & COLLECTION
Before heading to your nominated starting venue, swing by the official registration point to collect your wristband, tasting glass & vouchers.
📍 Where: Panhead Tory St (1 Tory St)
🗓️ When: Saturday 18th October | 11am – 1pm
Please note: The Urban Wine Walk officially runs from 12-4pm. Arrive early to grab your event pack and avoid the rush!
REFUND POLICY
Tickets are non-refundable (we’re all in for good times rain, hail or shine!). The only exception is if the event is cancelled or postponed by the organisers – then we’ve got you covered.
GETTING AROUND
One of the best parts about the Urban Wine Walk...? It’s totally self-guided! After checking in at your nominated starting venue, the day is yours! Wander at your own pace, discover new spots and sip your way through the trail however you like.
**Sorry kids, Urban Wine Walk is strictly 18 Years and Over!

description:
We 💛 Mac 'n' Cheese, A feast with purpose, where every bowl makes a difference.
Celebrate the final day of Visa Wellington On a Plate and the end of winter with the ultimate comfort food: mac 'n' cheese, served all day long.

Two of Wellington’s legendary food rescue and community dining champions, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh, are joining forces to serve piping hot mac 'n' cheese, raising funds to help feed the community. As official charity partners of the festival, they are turning comfort food into real impact.

For just $10, each bowl will help fund a three-course meal for someone in need through Everybody Eats or provide a day’s worth of food for a family via Kaibosh.

Customise your mac with a range of toppings and flavours, all made from rescued food, showcasing just how delicious food recovery can be. In the lead-up to the event, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh will be calling on their social media followers to share their favourite mac 'n' cheese combos, with the top picks featured on the day.

Diners can enjoy their meal seated in the Everybody Eats restaurant or opt for takeaway to share with the whānau or flat.

The goal is to serve 2,000 bowls and fund 2,000 meals for the community. Join the celebration, enjoy incredible kai and help make a real difference.

description:
Āhuru Kai Kōhua Poaka: Burger Wellington, The boil-up is a dish of love, traditionally made in big pots for whānau and friends. It brings people together. Te Papa wanted to capture the essence of this traditional Māori kai and give it a gourmet twist.

Traditional boil-up pork roulade, with Pagro lettuce and tomato, puha mousseline, and horopito aioli in a toasted Brezelmania watercress milk bun, with hand-cut kūmara fries, mānuka honey aioli, a shot of bone broth, and a heart-shaped raspberry framboise dessert.

Join us at the Te Papa Cafe on Level 1, walk-ins welcome. Reserve your spot by booking now.

Please note we aren’t able to accommodate dietary requirements.

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.

description:
China and the Media Landscape in the Pacific, Over the last decade, the People’s Republic of China has sought to deepen its ties with Pacific Island countries. Beijing’s efforts to cultivate influence in the region have included expanding economic, diplomatic, and security ties with Pacific Island nations, as well as expanding China’s footprint in the region’s media landscape. This talk will present the findings of recent research on China’s efforts to shape reporting, media coverage and narratives in the Pacific Islands and put Beijing’s efforts within the context of the region’s rapidly evolving information landscape.
 About the speakers:
Heidi Holz is a Senior Research Scientist at CNA. For close to two decades, her work has focused on PRC strategic communications, propaganda, and influence efforts. She is a graduate of Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service, where she received a master’s degree in security studies and a bachelor’s degree in Chinese and East Asian history.
Genevieve Collins is a research specialist in the China Studies program at CNA, where her research focuses on the behaviour of China’s state-run media and its reactions to US military operations and activities.
 Barbara Dreaver (Discussant) has been the Pacific Reporter for TVNZ 1 News since 2002, breaking stories uncovering social and economic issues affecting Pacific people living in New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. In 2020, she created a two-year training programme through Pacific Cooperation Broadcasting Ltd to support new Pacific journalists across the Pacific region. In the 2024 New Years Honours she was awarded an ONZM for services to investigative journalism and Pacific communities.
 About CNA: CNA is a non-profit, non-governmental research and analysis organization dedicated to providing independent and objective analyses to the U.S. government and the public. This talk will build on previous CNA research on China and the Pacific Islands media landscape which you can find at www.cna.org.

Drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan, Council manages over 130 parks and reserves on your behalf – from playgrounds, sports grounds, and esplanades to scenic and native reserves.
We’re drafting an omnibus Reserve Management Plan to set out objectives, polices and rules that guide their use, management, protection and development and want your help. Tell us what you value about your favourite parks and reserves, what might impact their use, protection and enjoyment, and what ideas do you have for their future.
There's lots of ways to have your say - online, on paper and in person.
Come and chat to our Open Space Planning team
Thursday 28 August, 4pm–7pm, Coastlands Shopping Centre
Saturday 30 August, 9am–1pm, Maclean Park, skatepark
Saturday 6 September, 9am–1pm, Waikanae Park, old skatepark
Sunday 14 September, 9am–1pm, Ōtaki Centennial Park
Further information and ways to provide feedback can be found at haveyoursay.kapiticoast.govt.nz/RMP
label: Government & Politics

description:
Dropping Flyers Across Motukairangi, Flyer Drop Blitz - Mission Motukairangi
Kia ora e te whānau,
I’d love your help to blitz this flyer-dropping mission across the magnificent Motukairangi!
I’ve got a list of streets that need finishing off, and with your help we can get it done in no time.
Meet at my place, 11am
From there we’ll divide up and set off on your mission (should you choose to accept it
).
Every flyer in a letterbox is another step closer to connecting with our neighbours and sharing the kaupapa of this campaign.
Bring comfy shoes, a smile, and your best flyer-dropping energy!
label: Government & Politics

description:
From Europe to the Indo-Pacific: Finnish views on strategic partnerships and security in times of uncertainty, Finland, which shares a 1300km land border with Russia, has had its strategic circumstances dramatically impacted by the war in Ukraine. In this talk, State Secretary Pasi Rajala will discuss Europe’s evolving security landscape and its implications for Finland and NATO. He will share Finnish views on enhancing security and national resilience in response to shifting dynamics across Europe, the Indo-Pacific, and the global stage. He will also speak to the importance of deepening cooperation between Finland and New Zealand, two like-minded partners committed to democratic values, multilateralism, and the rules-based international order.
Mr. Pasi Rajala is State Secretary to Foreign Minister Elina Valtonen and Defence Minister Antti Häkkänen. He has previously served as Special European Affairs Adviser to the Finnish Prime Minister, Special Adviser to the Minister for Trade and Development, and Press Counselor and Spokesperson at the Finnish Embassy in Washington, D.C. Prior to that he held a number of communications positions, including in development finance company Finnfund, PR agency EuroRSCG, and the UN Development Program. Mr. Rajala holds a Master of Social Sciences degree from the University of Helsinki where he majored in International Relations.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Government Digital Transformation in Latin America - what can we learn?, We are excited to announce the latest in our series of talks on Digital Transformation, in partnership with Silverstripe.
María Inés Baque will be joining us online from Argentina to share her expert insights and experiences on the key goals, capabilities, opportunities and challenges for government digital transformation - with a range of use cases from around Latin America.
María Inés Baque is Government Transformation Advisor for Latin America, Canada, and the Caribbean (LCC) at AWS. She served as secretary of digital government and technology innovation in Argentina from 2016 to 2019. She coordinated the Digital Agenda 2030 and led the transformational efforts in the areas of digital services, digital inclusion, open government, open data and new technologies adoption.
Global awards and recognitions she has received include Innovation Lab, Tel Aviv, 20 exceptional GovTech Leaders (2020), Women Corporate Directors 2019 and The 100 Most Influential People in Digital Government, Apolitical, 2018.
She was co-chair of the G20 Digital Economy Taskforce for Gender Inclusion in 2018 that issued the Bridging the Digital Gender Divide report.
Before government, her career was in global IT and financial services enterprises. She focused on process reengineering, startups, IT management, outsourcing and business process operations.
You may attend in person at the MBIE offices (limited to 40 people - there will be some food courtesy of Silverstripe), or you may tune in online via Microsoft Teams (the link will be at the bottom of your order confirmation email). If you choose to attend in person please arrive at 11.50am so there is time for you to sign in, pick up some food, and be seated before we begin. There will be time for questions after the presentation.
label: Government & Politics

description: Greater Wellington Regional Council Debate | Democracy Week, The Greater Wellington Regional Council keeps an eye on all things outdoors from Lyall Bay to Masterton. Buses, trains, water and parks; these folk keep these things running. Come listen to them debate for their chance to win your vote. Featuring Daran Ponter, Tom James, Sarah Free, Henry Peach & Thomas Kay (with others TBC).

description:
HRA Meet The Candidates, You are cordially invited to attend the Hataitai Residents Association Meet the Candidates meeting on Sunday 14th September at the:
Wellington Cadet Centre
393 Evans Bay Parade.


With the large number of Council and Mayoral candidates, we have decided to split the meeting into 2 parts.


Eastern Ward Candidates,

Mayoral Candidates,

-Each candidate will have 2 ½ minutes for a speech.
-After the speeches we will have a question-and-answer session until 3.15pm.


We will have coffee and tea after.

description:
It's in the Ballot - CDC – Carterton Councilor at Large -In-studio, Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025

description:
Living Wage Local Government Election Forum – Hutt, Living Wage Local Government Election Forum – Hutt
We need you to join us to keep HCC a Living Wage Council – and to push for more for our city’s lowest-paid workers.

Arrive from 6.00 pm, forum starts 6.30 pm sharp

At this forum, we’ll be asking mayoral and council candidates to commit to:

✅ Keeping HCC a Living Wage Employer
✅ Supporting a Living Wage for the new water entity
✅ Championing the Living Wage to help make the Hutt a Living Wage City

See you there,

Make sure to register!

You may also like the following events from Living Wage Aotearoa New Zealand:
Next Wednesday, 3rd September, 08:00 am, Living Wage Local Government Election Forum – Wellington in Wellington
Also check out other Business events in Lower Hutt.

description:
Mayoral and Tawa Community Board Candidates evening, You’re invited to hear from the Candidates for Mayor of Wellington and the Tawa Community Board.
Come along for your chance to ask your burning questions of your candidates.
The event will be held in the main hall at the Tawa Community Centre, which is an accessible venue with ample parking, and close to public transport links.
Doors will be open from 6:45pm.
7:00 Welcome from the Chair and safety briefing
7:05 - 7:20 Tawa Community Board candidates speak to the audience (2 minutes each in random order selected on the night)
7:20 - 8:00 Tawa Community Board Candidates answer questions from the floor
8:00 - 8:05 Quick reset to Mayoral Candidates
8:05 - 8:30 Mayoral Candidates speak to Audience (2 minutes each in random order)
8:30 - 9:00 Mayoral candidates answer questions from the floor
9:00 - 9:30 Time to mingle or ask remaining questions.
If you can’t make it, you can still submit your questions. Leave a comment with your question or email it to vibrant.tawa@gmail.com (clearly stating if the question is for Mayoral candidates, Community Board candidates, or both).
Follow this link to submit any questions you would like answered on the night
https://forms.gle/mycYjBoEWDVafq938
label: Government & Politics

description:
Meet Your Candidates, Meet Your Candidates
Porirua’s local elections are in October 2025 – come and meet the candidates who want to represent you as mayor, and as councillors in the Parirua Māori and Onepoto Wards.

Join us for a friendly, panel-style event where you’ll hear about the candidates’ backgrounds, their connections to the Bay, and share a few laughs too.

There will be no questions taken from the floor on the night but you are welcome to send your questions before hand to

Let’s talk about the future of our community – see you there!

#MeetYourCandidates #TitahiBay #PoriruaElections2025 #PariruaMāoriWard #OnepotoWard

description:
Meet the Candidates | Paraparaumu, Meet the Candidates | Paraparaumu
These events are organised by Kāpiti Coast District Council. To see the full list of Council organised 'Meet the Candidates' events, visit www.kapiticoast.govt.nz/meetthecandidates

Except for the mayoral debate, which will be a facilitated debate dedicated to mayoral candidates, our Meet the Candidate events will involve inviting all candidates running for Mayor, districtwide Councillor, Māori Ward Councillor, and Ward Councillor and Community Board Member positions for that ward to attend.

They will each be provided a dedicated space for them to present their candidacy and have conversations with the community who can attend at any time during the two-hour slots.

Meet the Candidates events help voters:
🔹 meet and hear from candidates
🔹 learn where they stand on issues affecting our District
🔹 make informed decisions when voting in the local elections 2025.

You may also like the following events from Kāpiti Coast District Council:
Next Monday, 1st September, 12:00 am, Dying Matters Week 2025 in Paraparaumu
Next Friday, 5th September, 11:00 pm, Waikanae drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan in Waikanae
Next month, 22nd September, 08:30 am, Meet the Candidates | Mayoral debate in Paraparaumu
label: Government & Politics

description:
Meet the Candidates – A Business Community Conversation - Paraparaumu, Meet the Candidates – A Business Community Conversation - Paraparaumu
This September, the Kāpiti Business Chamber is partnering with the Ōtaki and Te Horo, Waikanae and Raumati Business Associations to host two “Meet the Candidates” events for our business community.

With local elections just around the corner, these sessions are your opportunity to engage directly with incoming candidates, hear their views on local business issues, and share what matters most to you.

What to expect:
A curated panel-style conversation with standing candidates
Open mic Q&A for business owners and professionals
Subsidised drinks and light nibbles
A chance to connect with others in your area

📍 Paraparaumu – Wednesday 10 September, 5.30pm, Paraparaumu Rugby Club

We’ve intentionally chosen two locations to make it easier for business owners across the district – from Waikanae and Raumati to Te Horo and Ōtaki – to attend their closest event.

These are free events, but RSVPs are essential.

You may also like the following events from Kāpiti Business Chamber:
This October, 22nd October, 07:00 am, Procurement & Contract Myths – The Good, The Bad & The Ugly. in Paraparaumu
Also check out other Sports events in Paraparaumu.

description:
Meet the Candidates, hosted by Cycle Wellington and Bicycle Junction, Meet the Candidates, hosted by Cycle Wellington and Bicycle Junction
Please register,for free, at https://events.humanitix.com/meet-the-candidates-cycling-edition so we know how many people are coming.
How people get around our city and suburbs is a critical issue for Wellington.
Safe public spaces is core Council business. We believe that a network of protected bike lanes is an essential part of a safe and modern city that seeks to attract growth businesses and their staff. Wellington has made good progress but we need to keep going.
Hear about Council candidates' visions and plans for Wellington.
Please join members of Wellington’s cycling community for an informal meeting.

Also check out other Sports events in Wellington, Meetups in Wellington, Trips & Adventurous Activities in Wellington.
label: Government & Politics

description: Meet the Greater Wellington Regional Council Candidates, There are 11 candidates wanting to be part of the GWRC. And 3 candidates for the Māori Ward. What do they want to achieve and how do regional councils and Māori wards fit into the future of our region? Come along and find the answers
label: Government & Politics

description:
Meet the candidates - Cycling Edition, Help ensure the next council stays bike-positive!
Things are tough right now. It is shameful how many measures the government has taken to worsen conditions on our roads and streets, making journeys less safe for everyone. The terrible choices made by national politicians makes it even more important to elect local representatives who will continue fighting to make our streets work for the people of Wellington out on their bikes.
Join Cycle Wellington to hear from local election candidates about their vision and perspectives on cycling and bike infrastructure for Pōneke.
Voting opens Tuesday 9 September and closes midday Saturday 11 October 2025.
More information is available on the WCC website.
label: Government & Politics

description:

Come and meet the Northern General Ward Candidates. Hear what they have to say during a Q + A session followed by a meet and greet of your candidates. We are playing our part as a responsible, Community minded business by hosting this event and will be requiring a high standard of behaviour.

Prime Minister movie fundraiser, Described as a moving and poignant account of Dame Jacinda Ardern’s time as Prime Minister of New Zealand. An intimate look into the complexities and challenges of leading a country while also staying true to your values. Beforehand (all going well) we’ll share staff photos of her time as leader, never previously shared in public.
Funds go to the campaign to get our Western Ward councillor to join a full team of Labour Councillors to support the Mayor so we can get things done for working Wellingtonians and those who need our support.

description:
Public Meeting on the Ōwhiro Bay Bus network, Come along to a public meeting on the Ōwhiro BayBus network hosted by Better Buses Owhiro Bay!
This event will feature a presentation by the co-founders of Better Buses Ōwhiro Bay, as well as residents discussing the impact the poor bus services have had on them. This event will be an opportunity to learn deeply about the poor services, connect with other residents who all face the same issues, and meet with candidates who can solve this issue.
Candidates for the Greater Wellington Regional Council and WCC Southern Ward will be present as well, and media will be invited to cover the meeting.
label: Government & Politics

description:

Because of Luxon’s underfunding, GP fees are heading towards $100. description:
Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War, Dr Ian Storey will discuss his new book on Russia’s relations with Southeast Asia. The first major study of Russia and Southeast Asia since the end of the Cold War, it traces the dramatic shifts in Moscow’s relations with the region since President Vladimir Putin took power in 2000. Dr Storey assesses the legacy of the Soviet Union, charts the evolution of Putin’s foreign policy and identifies the drivers behind the Kremlin’s ‘Turn to the East’ or Asia pivot. His book also examines Russia’s dialogue partnership with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the development of Moscow’s political, economic and military ties with each of the 11 regional states over the past 25 years. A large part of the book is devoted to Southeast Asia’s responses to Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. At the end of the talk Dr Storey will also provide an update of Russia-Southeast Asia relations in 2025 and how the region views the on-going Russia-Ukraine War.
Dr Ian Storey is a Senior Fellow at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore. He specializes in regional security issues, focusing on Southeast Asia’s relations with the major powers and maritime security, especially the South China Sea dispute. Since joining ISEAS in 2007 he has been the editor of the ISEAS academic journal Contemporary Southeast Asia. Prior to ISEAS, Ian held academic positions at the Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies, Hawaii and at Deakin University, Australia. Ian received his PhD from the City University of Hong Kong, his Master’s degree from the International University of Japan and his BA (Hons) from the University of Hull, England. He is the author of Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War (2025) and Southeast Asia and the Rise of China: The Search for Security (2011)

description:
Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order, Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order
Associate Professor Christina Lai will speak on Taiwan's trade practices against the backdrop of Cross-Strait tensions

About this Event

Abstract
Over the last decade, China has punished countries that undermine its territorial claims and foreign policy goals with measures such as restricting trade, encouraging popular boycotts, and cutting off tourism. These coercive measures have caused significant economic damage to U.S. partners such as Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Australia. This talk focuses on Taiwan’s response to China’s economic sanctions, highlighting the agency of medium-sized countries in the shadow of a great power.
The second part of this presentation will propose a common understanding of the liberal international order in which state and non-state actors follow rules, norms, and legal procedures in conducting international affairs. This rule-based practice is an essential part of the Asian regional order. If Taiwan were integrated into the multilateral institutions in Asia, the chance of conflict would be greatly reduced. The future of Taiwan also depends on the resilience of the liberal international order and other middle-power states in the Asia Pacific.


Bio
Christina Lai is an Associate Research Fellow in the Institute of Political Science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan. Dr. Lai received her Ph.D. in Government from Georgetown University. In 2015-2016, she was a post-doctoral fellow in China and the World Program at Princeton University. She is interested in U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, Chinese Foreign Policy, East Asian politics, and Qualitative Research Methods. Her works have appeared in the Politics, International Politics, Political Science, PS: Political Science & Politics, Journal of Contemporary China, Pacific Review, and Asian Security.



Agenda


🕑: 04:30 PM - 05:30 PM
Welcome reception with refreshments and light catering

🕑: 05:30 PM - 06:30 PM
Keynote address: Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal Intern
Host: Christina Lai

description:
The Challenges of Peacebuilding, In this conversation, Dr David Harland will reflect on his experience working as a mediator and negotiator in conflict zones and his role as Director of the Geneva-based Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue. The Centre was awarded the Carnegie Wateler Peace Prize in 2022 “for its track record of finding the means, including mediation, to bring parties together and end conflicts”. Its work has included involvement in Aceh and Mindanao, assisting with the disbanding of the Basque separatist group ETA, and the Black Sea Grain Initiative. David will share insights on the challenges of peacebuilding in an era of growing competition and contestation.
Dr David Harland is a former New Zealand diplomat and Executive Director of the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), a Geneva-based foundation that specialises in the mediation of armed conflict. He previously worked for the United Nations, including in Bosnia, Kosovo, Haiti and Timor Leste, and he wrote the UN Secretary-General’s landmark report on the fall of Srebrenica. David serves on the UN Secretary-General’s high-level advisory board on mediation. He has degrees from Harvard University, Tufts University, Beijing University and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington.
The event will be followed by light refreshments.

description:
The Liberal International Order as a Core-Periphery Order: An Alternative History with Multiple Deep Contestations, I offer an alternative macrohistory of the Liberal International Order (LIO) that was explicitly designed to perpetuate Western dominance and American hegemony. The LIO is better understood as a core-periphery order because inequality between the Western-core and the ‘Restern’-periphery was constitutive of it. (Re-)Imperialism—not just liberalism—remained a central ordering mechanism well after 1945. I show the two-way deep contestations between the liberal and anticolonial ordering projects, especially at the 1955 Bandung Conference. Contra the post-LIO pessimism of disorder/chaos, I argue that the normative agency of the Southeast Asian states informed by the legacy of Bandung is heralding a multiplex, multi-regional world order. As the declining inequality between the West and Asia transforms the core-periphery LIO, the emergent decentered world order will lack a core, whether Western/liberal or Asian. This deep transformation should be welcomed, not deeply contested, although coexistence and global integration require embracing deep pluralism, not liberalism.
Manjeet S. Pardesi is Associate Professor of International Relations in the Political Science and International Relations Programme, and Asia Research Fellow at the Centre for Strategic Studies at Victoria University of Wellington. His research interests include World Orders and World/Global History, Great Power Politics, Asian security, and the Sino-Indian rivalry. His most recent book, Divergent Worlds: What the Ancient Mediterranean and Indian Ocean Can Tell Us About the Future of International Order (co-authored with Amitav Acharya) was published by Yale University Press in 2025.

with Kadam Birgit

By keeping Atisha’s Advice in our heart, we can maintain a peaceful happy mind, our human nature and good qualities will improve, we will be able to show a good example for the people of our troubled world and we will quickly attain full enlightenment.

As Venerable Geshe-la says, ‘Simply putting this Advice into practice we will naturally become a Bodhisattva, a holy compassionate being who is the object of everybody’s love and respect’.

On this half day course Kadam Birgit will share teachings given at the International Summer Festival 2025 on Advice from Atisha’s Heart.

Although it was composed many centuries ago, this much-loved Buddhist scripture is full of practical advice to help us deal with the challenges of modern living, and transform our life into an authentic path of inner development.

Everyone welcome.

WHAT TO EXPECT
These classes are based on Buddha’s teachings on the mind, but you do not need to be a Buddhist to attend, or to benefit from them. There is no physical exercise involved and you can choose to sit either in a chair or on a cushion. These classes are suitable for all levels of experience.

𝘾𝙤𝙣𝙩𝙧𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣𝙨:

Breathwork results in certain specific physiological changes in the body and also can result in intense physical and emotional release.

As a precaution, the following conditions are contraindicated in certain breathwork practices.

It is crucial that you inform your breathwork practitioner if any of the following conditions are relevant to you:

• Pregnancy (at any stage)

• Severe PTSD or trauma

• Currently using recreational drugs

• Recent surgery

• Taking any medication that alters brain chemistry like anti-anxiety,anti-depressant, ADD, OCD medications, etc.

•Detached Retina

•Glaucoma

•Kidney disease

•High Blood Pressure

•Cardiovascular disease, including angina, previous heart attack or stroke
•Diagnosis of aneurysm in the brain or abdomen

•Uncontrolled thyroid conditions

•Diabetes

•Severe Asthma— for mild to moderate asthma, we can discuss but you must bring your inhaler to the session.

• Epilepsy

• History of Seizures

• Prior diagnosis of bipolar disorder, schizophrenia or previous psychiatric condition.

•Any other medical, psychiatric or physical conditions which would impair or affect the ability to engage in any activities that involve deep physical and/or emotional release.

𝙁𝘼𝙌’𝙨:

What can I expect?

There will be a short guided meditation, explanation of conscious connected breathwork (how to do it, tetany, things that may happen etc), a full 60 min breathwork journey and space afterwards for a few to share about their experience and any questions asked and support given if needed.

I have one or more of the listed contraindications - what should I do?

Email or message Tara to let her know what these are and she’ll let you know if she can offer adjustments so you can attend.

description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset, Breathwork: A Gentle Reset
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset

Take a pause from the noise of daily life.

This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.

You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:

A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages

A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding

Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.

To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.

Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.

Why Breathwork?

Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.

You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.

Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.

description:
Community Agency - a conversation with Markus Luczak-Roesch and Gerhard Reese, Two scholars share their perspectives on Community Agency and discuss the links between the Global environmental and global mental health crises.
  Gerhard Reese
Gerhard Reese works as Associate Professor for Climate Change at Te Herenga Waka - Victoria University Wellington in Aotearoa / New Zealand. Before, he was Professor and head of the Environmental Psychology Research Unit at the University Kaiserslautern-Landau in Germany since 2016. He got his PhD in Psychology from Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Germany, in February 2010. His research focuses on individual, social and systemic catalysts and barriers of pro-environmental behaviour and the nature-health nexus. He attempts and sometimes succeeds to spend more time outdoors than indoors and he still is a serious competitor in Super Mario Kart.
Markus Luczak-Roesch
Markus Luczak-Roesch is Professor of Informatics and the inaugural Chair in Complexity Science at Victoria University of Wellington’s School of Information Management. He is also one of two Co-Directors of Te Pūnaha Matatini, Aotearoa New  Zealand’s Centre of Research Excellence in Complex Systems. He founded and leads the Complexity & Connection Science Lab, an interdisciplinary group developing theories and computational tools to understand how complex systems unfold over time. His research investigates how structure and meaning emerge in systems - from language and brain activity to online communities and the environment - using models that reveal meaningful coincidences and unexpected system-level behaviors.

Death Cafe Newtown, Death Cafe runs monthly on the 2nd Saturday.
Let's normalise our own demise! We are all going to die, let's talk about it. At a Death Café people - often strangers - gather to eat cake, drink tea and discuss death. Death Café is not a grief support group, or counselling session - instead it is a place to discuss death without expectations. description:
Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions, Doctors For Nutrition and MTM Community Project invite you to an evening of inspiration, education, and connection at our next ‘Dine with a Doc’ dinner.
Join us for a presentation on ‘The Power of Plant-Based Nutrition and Lifestyle Interventions for Preventing Chronic Disease’—an event designed to empower everyone from healthcare professionals to health-conscious community members. You will also be the first to hear about the new MTM Community Project, and about their mission. 
When: 6:30pm – 9:30pm, Tuesday, 19th August 2025
Where: Gear Homestead, 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Wellington
Price: $50 (includes dinner and non-alcoholic beverage)
At this event, Dr Heleen Haitjema will take you on a journey through the clinical benefits of whole food, plant-based (WFPB) nutrition. Through easy-to-understand explanations of key concepts - such as endothelial dysfunction, intramyocellular lipid accumulation, and calorie density - you’ll discover how WFPB eating can dramatically improve health outcomes and transform lives. 
After the presentation, join us for a panel discussion and a Q&A session with Dr Haitjema and Dr Luke Wilson. 
The evening continues with a plant-based dinner curated by the chefs from MTM Community Project, served in the elegant setting of Gear Homestead. Enjoy the opportunity to connect and network with leading dietitians, specialists, GPs, and passionate members of New Zealand’s plant-based community.
Buy your tickets now; spaces are strictly limited!
Sponsored by: Little City Kombucha

description:
Draw It Out - Adult workshop, A gentle yet powerful tool for wellness (adults 18+) to access inner guidance.

Theme: Welcoming new possibilities
Learn how to listen to your feelings and find guidance from within, using a gentle powerful tool called Interactive Drawing Therapy.

This single workshop focuses on the theme of welcoming new possibilities, great if you are going through change, wanting to transition or entering a new phase.

Date
This is a single workshop
6.15pm-7.30pm
Monday 29 September

Cost
$46 total

Included in each session
You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance. No art skills are needed, more simple mark making.

This gentle yet powerful tool uses drawing and writing as a way to access your subconscious and to listen to your heart rather than your head for guidance. A tool often used in therapy, it is made accessible for self-care and community wellness through these workshops.

About Lara Phillips
Lara Phillips is a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy. With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.

“We all have the wisdom within to help ourselves, if given the space.”

For more workshops or to book individual sessions visit www.drawitout.co.nz

Liability disclaimer
Draw It Out offers creativity for wellbeing. It is not intended as therapy nor does it replace counselling, therapy, or any other medical or clinical professional help. Participants are guided to draw out where they are at, whilst drawing out their own inner resources for support and guidance.

Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.
